GUE_NGL requests revisions to impose strict timelines for Commission re-engagement with Parliament, amending Recital 9 to specify 30-day response requirements when legislative amendments exceed original scope.  

GUE_NGL warns that procedural delays caused by Member States' resistance to power-sharing fundamentally undermine the issue's transparency goals, requiring explicit sanctions in Article 4(2) against non-compliant institutions.  

GUE_NGL demands reinforced accountability clauses to align with their anti-technocratic principles, proposing amended wording in Section 3(c) to mandate public hearings before any trade measure adoption.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning the European Union’s common commercial policy, based on the Commission’s initial proposal (COM(2011)0349) and aligned with Article 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It adopted its first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the proposal are considered, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural accountability. The resolution referenced the Committee on International Trade’s report (A7-0096/2012) as foundational to its deliberations and instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional coordination and adherence to EU legislative processes.

title: Human rights, social and environmental standards in International Trade agreements: REPORT on human rights and social and environmental standards in international trade agreements
background: The European Union’s trade agreements have increasingly incorporated clauses on human rights, labor, and environmental standards, referencing UN conventions, ILO core norms, and multilateral environmental treaties. The Lisbon Treaty’s emphasis on external action coherence and existing frameworks like the Cotonou Agreement shape this approach. The Parliament will discuss integrating these standards into international trade agreements.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the legally binding integration of human rights and environmental standards in trade agreements, aligning with their commitment to fair competition and sustainable development.  
EPP approves the stringent enforcement mechanisms including GSP+ suspension for violations, effectively advancing EPP's priority of corporate accountability and ethical trade practices.  
EPP endorses the emphasis on corporate social responsibility clauses, highlighting their successful inclusion in agreements with South Korea and Colombia as a model for future negotiations.  
EPP proposes enhancing policy coherence by urging parallel advancements in environmental frameworks to complement trade measures, ensuring balanced responsibility across EU policy areas.  
EPP recommends safeguarding the EU’s agricultural self-sufficiency in climate-related trade provisions, amending critiques of the common agricultural model to prioritize food security alongside environmental goals.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s mandate for legally binding social and environmental clauses in trade agreements, aligning perfectly with their commitment to combat labor exploitation and ecological harm through enforceable frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on corporate accountability via OECD guidelines and binding arbitration, which directly addresses their concerns about transnational corporations’ unchecked environmental and labor abuses.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening human rights clauses in existing FTAs, such as the Colombia agreement, to ensure they transcend formulaic language and deliver tangible protections against rights violations.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the creation of a World Environmental Organization and enhanced ILO authority as critical steps to institutionalize sustainability and labor equity in global trade governance.  
GREEN_EFA urges accelerated implementation of the “carbon inclusion mechanism” and stricter GSP+ conditionality to prevent CO2 leakage and social dumping, reflecting their demand for trade policy that prioritizes planetary boundaries.

SD strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on legally binding environmental clauses, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to combat climate change through trade policy tools like carbon inclusion mechanisms.  
SD approves the call for stricter enforcement against forced labor, urging an expansion of import bans to include water resources traded unsustainably as highlighted in the debate.  
SD proposes enhancing border tax adjustments for non-compliant states to strengthen reciprocity, converting Kriton Arsenis’s critique into a measurable enhancement opportunity.  
SD applauds the focus on technology transfer via trade agreements, which directly advances SD’s priority of green innovation and North-South solidarity as stressed by George Sabin Cutaş.  
SD recommends adding explicit support for local production incentives to complement anti-dumping measures, ensuring coherence with the issue’s sustainability goals.

ECR rejects the issue's binding environmental clauses as incompatible with national sovereignty principles, particularly opposing EU-level enforcement of ILO standards.  
ECR absolutely doubts the carbon inclusion mechanism, viewing it as regulatory overreach inconsistent with market-driven solutions advocated in their 2023 trade manifesto.  
The proposal’s reliance on UN/WTO oversight conflicts with ECR’s stance against supranational governance structures, disregarding bilateral negotiation priorities.  
ECR condemns the blanket import ban approach for goods linked to modern slavery, arguing it undermines trade autonomy and fails to address root causes through partnership.  
The issue’s mandatory arbitration for corporate accountability overlooks critical aspects of voluntary OECD guideline adherence, a cornerstone of ECR’s trade policy framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative to integrate human rights, labor, and environmental standards into EU trade policy, emphasizing that trade agreements must serve as tools to promote universal values, fair competition, and sustainable development. It called for legally binding social and environmental clauses in all bilateral and multilateral agreements, including bans on child labor—particularly in natural stone extraction—and forced labor, with a certification system to ensure compliance with ILO Convention 182. The resolution stressed the need for reciprocity and differentiated approaches based on partners’ development levels, while opposing social or environmental dumping. It advocated for cooperation between the WTO and UN bodies like the ILO to align trade with human rights, proposing a World Environmental Organization post-climate agreement and a "carbon inclusion mechanism" to address CO2 leakage. The Parliament urged stricter enforcement of human rights clauses, including suspension of trade preferences under the GSP+ system for violations, and demanded EU import bans on goods linked to modern slavery. It highlighted the importance of transparency, civil society involvement, and parliamentary oversight in trade negotiations, aligning with the Lisbon Treaty’s objectives. Additionally, the resolution emphasized support for developing countries through fair Economic Partnership Agreements, sustainable fisheries, and adherence to UN Millennium Goals, while ensuring corporate accountability via OECD guidelines and binding arbitration for disputes. Environmental commitments included promoting green technologies, climate-friendly trade rules, and compliance with multilateral agreements like the Kyoto Protocol. The Parliament also called for regular impact assessments, monitoring of labor rights, and measures to prevent illicit capital flight, underscoring coherence between EU policies and global human rights obligations.

title: Regional Convention on pan-Euro-Mediterranean preferential rules of origin: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the regional Convention on pan-Euro-Mediterranean preferential rules of origin
background: Existing bilateral protocols on rules of origin under the Barcelona Process and Union for the Mediterranean framework, alongside post-2011 Arab Spring calls for enhanced regional economic integration, shaped efforts to streamline Euro-Mediterranean trade. The Parliament will discuss concluding a regional convention harmonizing preferential rules of origin and expanding cumulation across the pan-Euro-Mediterranean area.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's disproportionate focus on EU-Israel Protocol 4 implementation, which contradicts their stance on streamlined trade governance.  
EFD opposes the issue's structural imbalance, noting 40% of paragraphs critique a single agreement despite prior confirmation of its satisfactory application.  
EFD highlights fundamental inconsistency with DG Taxation's 2013 assessments, arguing the issue undermines trust in EU institutional coherence.  
EFD condemns the conflation of trade mechanisms with political conditionality, viewing this as naïve given post-Arab Spring regional instability.  
EFD asserts the issue fails to prioritize core cumulation benefits by diverting attention to non-germane bilateral disputes.

ALDE strongly endorses the harmonization of pan-Euro-Mediterranean rules of origin as a transformative tool to unlock South-South trade and empower SMEs, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable economic integration.  
ALDE applauds the convention’s simplification of over 100 bilateral protocols into a unified framework, effectively advancing their priority of creating transparent, accessible trade systems for democratizing Mediterranean economies.  
ALDE proposes strengthening transparency by mandating public disclosure of origin designations for Palestinian territories to prevent misuse of preferential terms, ensuring the agreement’s credibility aligns with international law.  
ALDE emphasizes the strategic urgency of swift ratification by all signatory states, noting delayed implementation risks undermining the convention’s potential to redistribute trade opportunities beyond oligarchic control.  
ALDE endorses the issue’s focus on cumulation mechanisms as critical to fostering regional production chains, consistent with their "Trade for Change" vision for post-Arab Spring economies.

SD strongly sanctions the convention’s harmonization of rules of origin as a critical step toward Euro-Mediterranean economic integration, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to reducing trade barriers and fostering regional stability through shared prosperity.  
SD approves the replacement of over 100 bilateral protocols with a unified framework but proposes enhancing dispute settlement mechanisms to ensure equitable enforcement across all signatory states.  
SD endorses the convention’s potential to spur economic growth in developing Mediterranean and Balkan countries, effectively advancing SD’s priority of poverty reduction through trade diversification.  
SD recommends strengthening provisions to exclude goods from occupied territories from preferential treatment, urging an upgrade of the EU-Israel Technical Arrangement to a legally binding agreement as a necessary safeguard.  
SD highlights the need for complementary initiatives to modernize customs cooperation and South-South trade frameworks, ensuring the convention serves as a foundation for deeper political and economic reforms.

GUE_NGL rejects the convention for failing to explicitly exclude goods from illegal Israeli settlements, enabling complicity in occupation and human rights violations  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue as reinforcing EU free-trade dogmas that prioritize multinational corporations over workers' rights and regional equity  
GUE_NGL condemns the lack of binding mechanisms to prevent Israel from exploiting trade preferences for settlement products, violating international law  
GUE_NGL fully doubts with the convention's alignment with unregulated trade zones that historically empower dictatorships and destabilize Mediterranean partners  
GUE_NGL demands immediate closure of all EU market access routes for settlement goods rather than creating new preferential loopholes

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Regional Convention on Pan-Euro-Mediterranean Preferential Rules of Origin, aimed at harmonizing rules of origin across Euro-Mediterranean countries to facilitate trade and cumulation of materials. The resolution endorsed the legal framework established by the Convention (referenced as 09429/2010) and aligned with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Articles 207 and 218), emphasizing its role in enhancing regional economic integration. It mandated the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its approval to the EU Council, Commission, national governments, parliaments of signatory states, and the Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, ensuring implementation and political alignment among all parties. The decision underscored the strategic importance of standardized rules of origin in reducing trade barriers and fostering cooperation within the Pan-Euro-Med zone.

title: Reinstatement of Myanmar/Burma's access to generalised tariff preferences: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 552/97 temporarily withdrawing access to generalized tariff preferences from Myanmar/Burma
background: Myanmar/Burma lost EU generalized tariff preferences (GSP) in 1997 following ILO-verified systemic forced labor under military rule. Post-2011 political reforms initiated democratization, prompting EU reassessment of trade relations under its GSP framework. The Parliament will discuss reinstating Myanmar/Burma’s tariff preferences amid evolving labor rights and governance conditions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the reinstatement of Myanmar’s GSP access as a strategic tool to reinforce democratic reforms through economic growth, aligning with their commitment to linking trade incentives with governance progress.  
EPP applauds the issue’s recognition of Myanmar’s efforts to eliminate systemic forced labor, matching their emphasis on human rights conditionality in trade agreements.  
EPP endorses the alignment with Aung San Suu Kyi’s explicit request for GSP restoration, reflecting their prioritization of local democratic leadership in EU external policy.  
EPP proposes enhancing post-reinstatement monitoring mechanisms to address ethnic conflicts in Rakhine and Kachin states, ensuring human rights benchmarks remain central to ongoing engagement.  
EPP approves the issue’s adherence to equal treatment principles for developing nations, consistent with their advocacy for non-discriminatory trade frameworks under the Everything But Arms initiative.

GREEN_EFA rejects the premature reinstatement of trade preferences as fundamentally incompatible with their human rights safeguards doctrine.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue’s removal of economic leverage while 130,000 Rohingyas remain systematically oppressed under Burmese authorities.  
This proposal directly contradicts GREEN_EFA’s requirement for verified prisoner releases and ethnic minority protections before trade normalization.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the abandonment of conditionality measures despite unresolved persecution documented by Human Rights Watch and other monitors.  
The issue’s failure to mandate immediate human rights assessments violates GREEN_EFA’s non-negotiable "rights before trade" framework.

ALDE strongly upholds the reinstatement of trade preferences as aligning with their commitment to incentivizing democratic transitions through economic engagement.  
ALDE applauds the linkage between tariff benefits and corporate transparency measures, particularly the proposed financial disclosure requirements for natural resource sectors.  
ALDE emphasizes the need to enhance monitoring of Rohingya rights protections and mining sector reforms as critical next steps for sustainable progress.  
ALDE approves the issue's focus on civil society oversight, urging EU institutions to formalize partnerships with Burmese NGOs for impact assessments.  
ALDE proposes strengthening Commission reporting requirements to verify implementation of labor and environmental standards before full preference restoration.

GUE/NGL totally doubts reinstating GSP while Myanmar's military persists in using white phosphorus against protesters and forcibly displaces ethnic communities, directly contravening the issue's claimed human rights priorities.  
GUE/NGL rejects the proposal’s geopolitical alignment with multinational resource extraction interests, which undermines grassroots Burmese movements demanding accountability for land confiscations and child soldier recruitment.  
The issue dangerously conflates limited reforms with irreversible progress, ignoring the European Parliament’s own documented evidence of systemic repression against Rohingya and Kachin minorities.  
GUE/NGL condemns the procedural haste to reinstate trade privileges as inconsistent with the party’s anti-imperialist mandate to center oppressed populations over corporate access strategies.  
By endorsing tariff reinstatement without binding human rights conditionalities, the proposal violates GUE/NGL’s core principle that economic engagement must follow—not precede—democratic and social justice guarantees.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its adoption of the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0524) concerning trade-related measures under Article 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, endorsing the proposal at first reading without amendments. It emphasized the need for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending to introduce substantial changes or replace it entirely, ensuring legislative oversight. The resolution further mandated the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence and inter-institutional communication.

title: Repeal of Council Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005 on the tariff rates for bananas: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005 on the tariff rates for bananas
background: The EU faced prolonged WTO disputes over discriminatory banana tariffs favoring African, Caribbean, and Pacific (ACP) countries, leading to a 2009 Geneva Agreement to reduce most-favored-nation tariffs and establish financial assistance for ACP producers. The Parliament will discuss repealing the 2005 tariff regulation to align with the WTO-brokered settlement.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the issue's alignment with WTO commitments and its role in resolving longstanding trade disputes through structured tariff reductions and financial support for ACP exporters.  
EPP applauds the balanced approach to global banana trade liberalization while safeguarding EU producers in outermost regions through enhanced POSEI funding frameworks.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need to update financial support mechanisms for EU banana growers to address tariff reduction impacts, proposing a review of POSEI allocations during the next financial perspective discussions.  
EPP welcomes the integration of the agreement into broader multilateral trade frameworks, reinforcing the EU's leadership in advancing fair and rules-based global trade.  
EPP underscores the importance of rigorous monitoring of the Banana Accompanying Measures to ensure ACP countries' competitiveness without compromising environmental or social standards.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the repeal of Council Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005, as it entrenches US multinational dominance in the banana market, directly conflicting with their commitment to equitable trade and small producer protection.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the tariff reduction framework for failing to address preference erosion for ACP countries, inconsistent with their advocacy for trade justice and support for vulnerable economies.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the insufficiency of the €190 million financial package, which overlooks critical aspects like sustainable local production and food sovereignty central to their principles.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s alignment with WTO commitments that prioritize market access over systemic reforms, contradicting their demand for radical overhaul of exploitative trade rules.  
GREEN_EFA asserts the proposal’s neglect of mandatory impact assessments and legislative amendments for sustainability, violating their manifesto emphasis on ecological and social safeguards.

SD strongly endorses the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005 as a critical step toward fulfilling the EU’s multilateral trade obligations under the Geneva Agreement, aligning with SD’s commitment to equitable global economic integration.  
SD applauds the €190 million Banana Accompanying Measures as essential to safeguarding ACP producers’ livelihoods, directly advancing SD’s priority of protecting vulnerable economies from asymmetric market pressures.  
SD proposes enhancing competition law enforcement mechanisms to prevent multinational monopolistic practices, ensuring the issue’s tariff reductions do not inadvertently harm small-scale producers or consumers.  
SD urges the Commission to formalize the 2020 impact assessment as a binding requirement to evaluate long-term effects on ACP nations and outermost regions, reinforcing transparency in trade policy outcomes.  
SD emphasizes integrating fair trade certification incentives into the agreement’s implementation to elevate labor and environmental standards, reflecting SD’s manifesto goals for ethical consumption.

GUE_NGL firmly doubts the repeal of Regulation 1964/2005 as it sacrifices ACP and EU outermost regions' small producers to multinational corporate interests, directly contradicting their anti-neoliberal trade principles.  
GUE_NGL rejects the €190 million compensation package as grossly inadequate to prevent the destruction of traditional banana farming communities, violating their commitment to economic justice.  
GUE_NGL condemns the agreement's alignment with WTO priorities over environmental and worker protections, highlighting its incompatibility with their manifesto's demand for trade policy democratization.  
GUE_NGL denounces the exclusion of ACP producers from negotiations as neo-colonial practice, directly opposing their decolonial trade solidarity principles.  
GUE_NGL declares the issue's market liberalization framework incompatible with their vision of food sovereignty, demanding complete rejection rather than technical adjustments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of a resolution endorsing the Agreement on Trade in Bananas, which resolves a longstanding WTO dispute through three key components: a schedule of tariff reductions for most-favoured nation (MFN) banana exporters, a framework for addressing "tropical products" and "preference erosion" in WTO negotiations, and a €190 million financial package (Banana Accompanying Measures) to support ACP banana exporters. The resolution supports abolishing the current EU MFN tariff rate of €176 per tonne for bananas by repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005, aligning with commitments under the Geneva Agreement. It welcomes the conclusion of the WTO dispute as politically and commercially significant, despite not fully reconciling all parties' interests, and affirms that the agreement will finalize EU market access commitments for bananas within the Doha Round agricultural negotiations. The Parliament endorsed the Commission’s proposal at first reading, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments arise, and emphasized integrating the outcomes into broader multilateral trade frameworks.

title: Opening of negotiations on a plurilateral agreement on services: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the opening of negotiations on a plurilateral agreement on services
background: Following stalled WTO Doha Round services negotiations since 2008 and increased post-crisis protectionism, the EU, representing 25.65% of global services exports, proposed plurilateral talks with 21 WTO members to enhance market access. The Parliament will discuss initiating EU participation in services agreement negotiations, balancing economic priorities with regulatory sovereignty and multilateral trade commitments.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the plurilateral services agreement as strategically vital to overcoming Doha Round stagnation and advancing EU competitiveness in key sectors like finance and e-commerce.  
EPP applauds the issue’s alignment with GATS principles, ensuring future multilateralization while safeguarding regulatory autonomy over public services.  
EPP endorses the inclusion of emerging economies through accession clauses, recognizing this as essential to counter protectionism and secure growth markets.  
EPP approves the two-year negotiation timeline as achievable given political will, though proposes monitoring implementation phases to balance ambition with operational feasibility.  
EPP emphasizes that excluding cultural services and maintaining procurement rules directly reflects their commitment to protecting European policy sovereignty.

GREEN_EFA rejects the TISA negotiations as entirely disapproveing with their commitment to multilateral trade governance under the WTO framework.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the lack of mandatory sustainability impact assessments, which the issue fails to require before advancing market access commitments.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the exclusion of BRICS and African nations from negotiations while maintaining incompatible liberalization demands that perpetuate unequal trade dynamics.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the assertion of WTO compatibility, demanding explicit legal guarantees to prevent corporate challenges to public service regulations.  
GREEN_EFA rejects plurilateral agreements as undermining democratic accountability, citing the Council’s bypassing of parliamentary consultation on the mandate.

ALDE strongly endorses advancing services liberalization through TISA negotiations, aligning perfectly with their commitment to open markets and innovation-driven economic growth.  
ALDE emphasizes preserving member states' sovereign right to regulate public services, proposing explicit treaty language to exempt existing public monopolies from privatization pressures.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s transparency requirements, urging real-time disclosure of negotiation texts to uphold democratic accountability in trade policymaking.  
ALDE endorses ambitious market access timelines but advises extending sustainability impact assessments to cover digital service inequalities in developing economies.  
ALDE stresses strategic outreach to BRICS nations post-agreement, advocating dedicated accession incentives to multilateralize high-standard rules globally.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the TISA negotiations for failing to exclude water, education, and healthcare from privatization threats, directly conflicting with their mandate to protect public services.  
GUE_NGL opposes the Council’s undemocratic mandate approval process, demanding full parliamentary oversight to prevent corporate capture of essential services.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s omission of binding safeguards against deregulation in sectors like insurance and consumer contracts, which undermines linguistic rights and liability protections.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s incompatibility with democratic accountability, insisting on immediate public disclosure of all negotiation texts to combat secrecy.  
GUE_NGL asserts that TISA’s market-access focus contradicts EU treaty principles, prioritizing profit over social welfare and environmental sustainability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the stagnation of multilateral trade negotiations under the WTO’s Doha Round, emphasizing the critical role of services—constituting 75% of EU GDP and employment, 28% of EU exports in 2011, and 25.65% of global services exports—in sustaining economic competitiveness. It highlighted the outdated and inconsistent nature of GATS commitments, which fail to reflect current trade barriers or autonomous liberalization efforts, and noted the rise of protectionist measures post-2008. The resolution welcomed the EU’s participation in plurilateral Trade in Services Agreement (TISA) negotiations, aiming to advance high-standard liberalization and regulatory disciplines (e.g., transparency, competition, licensing) while preserving the right to regulate public services. It stressed the need for TISA to align with GATS principles, include an accession clause for future multilateralization, and exclude cultural and audiovisual services to protect EU policies. Concerns were raised over the absence of BRICS, ASEAN, and African countries—key growth markets with significant barriers—from negotiations, urging their inclusion without diluting ambition. The Parliament criticized the Council for approving the mandate without prior consultation and demanded ongoing transparency, including a sustainability impact assessment addressing social and environmental impacts. It endorsed a two-year timeline for concluding TISA, contingent on achieving robust market access commitments, standstill/ratchet clauses to lock in liberalization, and addressing procurement and subsidy rules stalled in WTO talks.

title: Protection against dumped and subsidised imports from countries not members of the EU: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Community and Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Community
background: The EU's existing trade defense regulations (1225/2009 and 597/2009) faced challenges from evolving global trade practices, increased non-EU subsidized imports, and high-profile cases like Chinese solar panels (2013). The Commission proposed modernization (COM(2013)0192) to address enforcement gaps and WTO compliance. The Parliament will discuss amendments to strengthen protections against dumped and subsidized imports while balancing market openness and EU industry interests.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the modernization of trade defense instruments as essential for protecting EU industries from distorted competition, particularly endorsing measures against environmental and social dumping practices.  
EPP approves the compromise package's SME facilitation measures, proposing accelerated investigation timelines to ensure smaller enterprises can effectively utilize anti-dumping tools.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of suspending the lesser duty rule in cases of raw material cost distortions, urging its judicious application to address paradigm shifts while preventing overreach.  
EPP advocates for pragmatic transitional arrangements regarding the shipping clause to maintain legal certainty for businesses, aligning with the need for balanced implementation.  
EPP urges swift Council action to finalize reforms before the legislative term ends, highlighting alignment with the party's 2023 competitiveness agenda for strategic autonomy.

GREEN_EFA fully approves the integration of international social and environmental standards into anti-dumping measures, perfectly aligning with their commitment to sustainable and equitable trade practices.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s critical role in preventing divisive external pressures like those seen in the Chinese photovoltaic case, ensuring unified EU industrial defense strategies.  
GREEN_EFA applauds enhanced SME access to trade defense mechanisms as a vital step toward balancing global market competitiveness with fair economic participation.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the mandate for parliamentary oversight, reinforcing democratic accountability in trade policy as a cornerstone of their governance principles.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the issue’s framework for addressing subsidy-driven market distortions, recognizing its alignment with climate-conscious industrial policy goals.

ECR rejects the proposal's structural failure to enforce member state compliance mechanisms, absolutely condemning with their demand for binding national trade defense implementation.  
ECR opposes the unresolved offshore zone loopholes as inconsistent with their requirement for territorial accountability in anti-dumping cases.  
ECR condemns the lack of WTO-aligned subsidy countermeasures, overlooking critical aspects of asymmetric competition from state-supported third-country exporters.  
ECR disputes the Council's procedural delays embedded in the issue, mirroring Muscardini's critique of institutional inertia blocking economic recovery.  
ECR absolutely condemns with the proposal's tolerance for non-transparent corporate registrations, perpetuating unfair trade practices against EU manufacturers.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to prohibit using trade instruments to coerce market access from developing nations, directly conflicting with their 2010 stance on resource sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the omission of binding measures against social/environmental dumping, which the issue overlooks despite UN Charter obligations for equitable cooperation.  
GUE_NGL condemns the regulation’s potential to institutionalize low raw material pricing, perpetuating wage suppression and poverty in violation of decent work principles.  
GUE_NGL disputes the proposal’s compatibility with Article 3 of the UN Charter, as it prioritizes commercial interests over solving economic inequalities through multilateralism.  
GUE_NGL declares the text illegitimate without Amendment 83’s explicit integration of environmental and labor safeguards, rendering it inconsistent with their anti-dumping framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal concerning international trade, adopting its first-reading stance to advance legislative procedures under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the original proposal (COM(2013)0192) are contemplated, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The resolution further directed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and institutional alignment in the EU’s trade policy framework.

title: Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the EC and Israel on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA): RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the State of Israel, of the other part, on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA)
background: The EU and Israel’s Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement (2000) established trade frameworks, with a 2010-negotiated Protocol on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA) aiming to reduce technical barriers. The EU maintains non-recognition of Israeli jurisdiction in territories occupied since 1967. The Parliament will discuss concluding the CAA Protocol under the existing agreement.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the ACAA protocol as a vital step in eliminating technical trade barriers, aligning with their commitment to deepening Euro-Mediterranean economic cooperation through regulatory alignment.  
EPP applauds the explicit exclusion of products from occupied territories under the protocol’s scope, emphasizing its consistency with EU positions on territorial applicability and Israel’s 1967 borders.  
EPP highlights the agreement’s consumer benefits, particularly accelerated access to high-quality generic pharmaceuticals for EU patients, which aligns with public health priorities and single-market efficiency goals.  
EPP proposes enhanced monitoring mechanisms to ensure territorial compliance, suggesting regular Commission reporting to maintain transparency without opposing the agreement’s core objectives.  
EPP underscores the importance of maintaining balanced EU-Israel relations, viewing the protocol as a technical instrument that strengthens shared standards while preserving the EU’s role as a neutral mediator in broader regional disputes.

GREEN_EFA rejects the protocol as it fundamentally disputes with their commitment to upholding international law and human rights in Palestinian territories.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the agreement for failing to guarantee traceability of products from Israeli settlements, directly contradicting EU diplomatic reports on origin verification.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the protocol’s political timing, arguing it rewards Netanyahu’s expansion of illegal settlements despite EU condemnation of such policies.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s inconsistency with the EU’s 2009 suspension of economic relations upgrades, undermining coherence in Middle East policy.  
GREEN_EFA asserts the agreement overlooks worsening Palestinian rights violations, prioritizing trade over accountability for occupation practices.

ECR strongly upholds the protocol as a technical trade facilitation measure, aligning with their commitment to barrier-free commerce and mutual recognition of high regulatory standards.  
ECR approves the exclusion of settlement-produced goods under Commission assurances, emphasizing Israel's democratic governance and pharmaceutical sector's compliance with EU safety requirements.  
ECR highlights the agreement's economic rationale, noting its potential to reduce medication costs for European patients through streamlined certification of Israeli generics.  
ECR rejects conflation with geopolitical issues, urging adherence to trade merits alone as demonstrated in identical protocols with other Mediterranean partners.  
ECR proposes enhancing the Commission's implementation reports with quarterly progress metrics on territorial compliance verification to reinforce transparency.

GUE_NGL rejects the protocol as a de facto political endorsement of Israel’s systemic oppression of Palestinians, firmly disputeing with their commitment to anti-colonial solidarity and human rights.  
GUE_NGL opposes the agreement’s framing as "technical," highlighting its role in integrating Israel into the EU single market despite ongoing illegal settlements and Gaza’s humanitarian crisis.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to address Israel’s blockade of Gaza, which directly contradicts EU principles on freedom of movement and access to essential medicines.  
GUE_NGL asserts that any economic cooperation with Israel legitimizes violations of international law, including the 2012 clarification’s inadequacy to prevent settlement-linked trade normalization.  
GUE_NGL demands unconditional rejection of the protocol, citing Israel’s violent interception of humanitarian aid ships as emblematic of policies incompatible with EU values.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement with Israel on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA), aimed at facilitating trade through mutual recognition of industrial product assessments. It emphasized the need for clarity on the territorial competence of Israeli authorities, following concerns addressed by Commissioner De Gucht’s July 2012 clarification that the protocol’s scope excludes Israeli settlements in occupied territories. The resolution called on the Commission to regularly report on the protocol’s implementation and instructed the Parliament’s President to communicate the decision to relevant EU and Israeli institutions. Key documents referenced include the draft Council decision (12428/2012) and the draft protocol (05212/2010), with committees on International Trade (INTA) and Foreign Affairs (AFET) overseeing procedural alignment under Treaty on the Functioning of the EU Articles 207 and 218.

title: State of play of the Doha development agenda: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda and preparations for the Ninth WTO Ministerial Conference
background: Initiated in 2001 to address trade imbalances and prioritize developing countries, the Doha Development Agenda faced prolonged negotiations, including a 2008 stalemate. With the Ninth WTO Ministerial Conference scheduled for December 2013 in Bali, the EU emphasized multilateral trade and WTO reform. The Parliament will discuss progress on the Doha Round and preparations for the Bali ministerial meeting.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's endorsement of plurilateral agreements like TiSA and GPA as firmly disputeing with their demand for strict multilateral WTO reform, which Franziska Keller explicitly denounced as undermining development priorities.  

GREEN_EFA opposes the proposal to differentiate among developing countries using "objective criteria" as inconsistent with their insistence on full, undiluted special treatment for LDCs in market access and services waiver implementation.  

GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's failure to mandate binding climate obligations in trade rules, overlooking critical aspects of environmental justice central to GREEN_EFA's platform, as highlighted in the debate's emphasis on climate change integration.  

GREEN_EFA rejects the limited ambition on cotton trade reforms and rules of origin adjustments, which the debate identified as non-negotiable for equitable LDC participation in global value chains.  

GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's silence on gender disparity mitigation in trade policy, directly contradicting their principle that trade systems must address structural inequalities as outlined by Keller.

ALDE strongly promotes the issue’s binding trade facilitation measures, which align perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to reducing bureaucratic barriers for SMEs and fostering equitable global trade growth.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on parliamentary oversight of WTO agreements, effectively advancing their manifesto goals for democratic accountability in multilateral trade governance.  
ALDE proposes organizing post-conference public dialogues with NGOs and businesses to enhance transparency and societal engagement, ensuring broader ownership of trade policy outcomes.  
ALDE highlights the opportunity to address corruption and tax fairness through parallel EU initiatives, complementing the issue’s development focus with governance reforms.  
ALDE endorses the push for plurilateral agreements like TiSA, which aligns with their vision for dynamic, rules-based trade frameworks that benefit competitive economies.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on strengthening parliamentary oversight of WTO decisions, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to democratic legitimacy in global governance through initiatives like the joint EU-Inter-Parliamentary Union conference.  
SD applauds the focus on trade facilitation as a growth catalyst, strongly endorsing binding agreements to streamline customs procedures in line with SD’s advocacy for equitable market access and poverty reduction.  
SD approves the emphasis on concluding the Doha Round’s development pillar, particularly duty-free access for LDCs, which directly advances SD’s priority of addressing systemic trade inequalities through instruments like the Everything but Arms initiative.  
SD proposes strengthening monitoring mechanisms for Aid for Trade commitments to ensure infrastructure funding reaches LDCs as intended, enhancing the issue’s existing call for renewed financial support.  
SD fully sanctions differentiation among developing countries using objective criteria, a position consistent with SD’s long-standing argument against blanket special treatment for advanced economies masquerading as developing nations.

GUE_NGL entirely againsts the issue's trade facilitation framework for prioritizing export infrastructure over regional development needs, which risks exploiting LDC budgets.  
GUE_NGL rejects the lack of binding financial commitments to build intra-regional trade capacities in developing countries, contrary to their demand for self-determined growth.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's silence on dismantling EU agricultural subsidies that undermine Global South farmers, a core Doha principle.  
GUE_NGL condemns support for plurilateral agreements like TiSA as undermining inclusive WTO negotiations, favoring corporate interests over democratic oversight.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to mandate parliamentary/civil society roles in trade talks, enabling opaque decision-making inconsistent with democratic trade governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for structural reform of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) to ensure a fair, open, and rules-based multilateral trading system that prioritizes development, particularly for least developed countries (LDCs) and low-income developing nations. It reaffirmed the Doha Development Agenda’s (DDA) objectives of addressing trade imbalances, fostering sustainable growth, and integrating developing countries into global value chains, while stressing the importance of special and differential treatment (S&DT) tailored to varying economic levels. The resolution highlighted the economic potential of a binding trade facilitation agreement, estimating it could boost global GDP by €68 billion annually through streamlined customs procedures, and urged enhanced Aid for Trade initiatives to counter reduced funding in 2011, particularly for infrastructure and capacity-building. It called for concluding the stalled Doha Round with an ambitious outcome at the 2013 Bali Ministerial Conference, emphasizing duty-free, quota-free access for LDCs (as in the EU’s Everything but Arms initiative) and implementation of the LDC services waiver. The Parliament supported plurilateral agreements like the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) and the revised Government Procurement Agreement (GPA), while advocating for technology transfers, renewed negotiations on the Information Technology Agreement, and extended TRIPS exemptions for LDCs until 2021. It stressed addressing non-tariff barriers, promoting environmental goods and services, and ensuring policy coherence between trade, development, and climate goals. The resolution also urged differentiation among developing countries based on objective criteria, greater parliamentary oversight of WTO decisions, and strengthened collaboration with international organizations to align trade with broader socio-economic objectives.

title: Report: Vital Moreira - Macro-financial assistance to Georgia: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision providing macro-financial assistance to Georgia
background: Following the 2008 global financial crisis and Georgia's military conflict with Russia, both Georgia and Armenia, as European Neighbourhood Policy partners, faced severe economic strain, fiscal deficits, and balance-of-payment challenges, leading to IMF-supported programs. The Parliament will discuss EU macro-financial assistance to address these countries' urgent financial needs.

stances.stance:
EPP fully agrees the immediate provision of macro-financial assistance to Georgia, perfectly aligning with its commitment to stabilizing Eastern Partnership economies post-conflict.  
EPP emphasizes the issue’s strict adherence to the Tagliavini Report’s findings, ensuring geopolitical coherence with EPP’s security priorities in the Caucasus region.  
EPP applauds the inclusion of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia as recipients, advancing the Union’s strategic goal of fostering stability in EU candidate regions through decisive economic solidarity.  
EPP underscores the urgency of bypassing protracted legislative debates, reflecting its principle of rapid crisis response to uphold EU influence in vulnerable partner states.  
EPP affirms that the grant-based structure for Georgia’s assistance exemplifies proactive fiscal diplomacy, consistent with its manifesto pledge to leverage financial tools for conflict recovery.

GREEN_EFA rejects the simplified procedure for Georgia's macro-financial assistance as it erodes parliamentary oversight, directly conflicting with their principle of transparent EU decision-making.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the Commission's delayed MFA implementation, which exacerbates Georgia's crisis while EU members like France arm Russia, the aggressor in the conflict.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally condemns with the absence of binding safeguards against military fund diversion, demanding explicit prohibitions aligned with their anti-militarization stance.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's silence on contradictory EU arms exports, which fuel regional instability and render financial aid strategically counterproductive.  
GREEN_EFA warns that the proposal overlooks systemic accountability, enabling geopolitical hypocrisy that undermines conflict issue efforts in the Black Sea region.

SD strongly accepts the provision of macro-financial assistance as crucial for stabilizing regions affected by economic crises, aligning with their commitment to European integration and regional solidarity.  
SD applauds the prioritization of urgent aid to address social discontent and ethnic sensitivities, ensuring stability in a historically fragile region.  
SD endorses the alignment of assistance with EU enlargement prospects, reinforcing their dedication to supporting aspirant states’ European futures.  
SD proposes expediting fund transfers by minimizing procedural delays tied to legal basis modifications, ensuring timely implementation without opposing the issue’s core objectives.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of this assistance to counter capital flight and unemployment, directly advancing economic resilience as outlined in their 2009 policy priorities.

ECR strongly upholds the provision of macro-financial assistance to Georgia as a strategic reinforcement of its EU-aligned economic ambitions, aligning perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to stabilizing Eastern Partnership states.  
ECR proposes enhancing the assistance amount beyond €46 million to better address Georgia’s post-conflict recovery needs and counterbalance Russian economic pressure, while maintaining the 2009 disbursement timeline.  
ECR approves the issue’s procedural safeguards but emphasizes eliminating bureaucratic delays to ensure Georgia receives critical 2009 funding without conditional bottlenecks.  
ECR applauds the linkage between assistance and Georgia’s energy corridor role, urging explicit recognition of this in implementation to advance EU diversification goals as outlined in their 2023 energy security agenda.  
ECR underscores the necessity of this aid as a geopolitical countermeasure, noting its alignment with Tagliavini Report findings on conflict impacts and Russia’s destabilizing regional influence.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the Commission’s 2009 proposal (COM(2009)0523) to the Council under Article 308 of the EC Treaty, emphasizing the need for alignment with the findings of the 2009 Tagliavini Report on the Georgia conflict. It mandated the Council to notify Parliament of any deviations from the approved text and to reconsult Parliament if intending substantial amendments to the Commission proposal. The resolution further instructed the Parliament’s President to transmit its position to the Council and Commission, ensuring procedural continuity while prioritizing adherence to the original proposal’s framework and the factual basis provided by the referenced international inquiry.

title: Report: Vital Moreira- Macro-financial assistance to Armenia: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision providing macro-financial assistance to Armenia
background: The global financial crisis and regional conflicts, including Georgia's 2008 military conflict with Russia, severely impacted Armenia, Georgia, Serbia, and Bosnia and Herzegovina, exacerbating fiscal deficits and balance-of-payments challenges under the European Neighbourhood Policy. The Parliament will discuss providing EU macro-financial assistance to address these economic crises.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely approves the immediate macro-financial assistance to Armenia as a critical measure to stabilize its balance of payments and budget deficits, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to fostering economic resilience in partner states.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the urgency of adopting assistance without procedural delays, emphasizing crisis response efficiency over extended legislative debate as mandated in the issue.  
EPP entirely approves extending support to Georgia’s post-conflict recovery, recognizing this as strategically vital for regional stability consistent with EU external action priorities.  
EPP strongly affirms the inclusion of Serbia and Bosnia-Herzegovina in assistance programs, viewing this as essential reinforcement of their EU candidacy pathways through economic stabilization.  
EPP perfectly aligns with leveraging macro-financial instruments as political solidarity tools, directly advancing the Union’s strategic interests in Eastern Partnership and Balkan regions.

GREEN_EFA rejects the macro-financial assistance framework for enabling systemic exclusion of parliamentary oversight through accelerated procedures, contradicting their democratic governance principles.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the failure to condition aid on strict non-military use guarantees, inconsistent with their pacifist stance against conflict escalation.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the proposal’s silence on EU member states’ arms trade with aggressor states like Russia, which directly undermines regional stability and necessitates such aid.  
 The issue’s procedural delays and geopolitical hypocrisy in addressing conflict root causes starkly conflict with GREEN_EFA’s demands for ethical coherence in foreign policy.

SD strongly approves the macro-financial assistance as a critical tool for stabilizing Balkan economies, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to regional solidarity and EU enlargement prospects.  
SD approves the urgency-driven approach, emphasizing that timely aid prevents social unrest exacerbated by unemployment and ethnic tensions in post-conflict regions.  
SD highlights the issue's strategic value in reinforcing EU influence through economic integration, effectively advancing SD's priority of fostering stability in aspiring member states.  
SD proposes streamlining Treaty of Lisbon-related procedural adjustments to avoid implementation delays while maintaining full compliance with legal frameworks.  
SD applauds the alignment of this assistance with broader EU crisis response mechanisms, mirroring SD's manifesto goals on proactive financial diplomacy.

ECR strongly promotes the macro-financial assistance framework as a vital tool to strengthen EU partnerships with Eastern neighbors, aligning perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to stabilizing post-conflict economies.  
ECR proposes enhancing Georgia's allocation beyond the proposed €46 million to better reflect its strategic importance and war-related economic setbacks, while fully endorsing the issue's core mechanisms.  
ECR emphasizes the urgency of uninterrupted 2009 disbursement, approving the procedural safeguards to prevent delays that could undermine Georgia's recovery trajectory.  
ECR applauds the issue's alignment with energy security priorities, noting that robust assistance to Caucasus states effectively advances ECR's priority of countering external dominance in critical supply corridors.  
ECR approves the Council-Parliament cooperation model but suggests expanding multi-year funding assessments to address protracted geopolitical instability in beneficiary countries.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the Commission’s proposal (COM(2009)0531) to amend existing legislation under Article 308 of the EC Treaty, endorsing its substantive content while emphasizing procedural cooperation with the Council. It mandated that the Council notify Parliament promptly if it intends to deviate from the approved text and reiterated the requirement for renewed consultation should the Council propose substantial amendments to the Commission’s original proposal. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its position to both the Council and the Commission, ensuring alignment in the legislative process.

title: Trade and investment strategy for the Southern Mediterranean following the Arab Spring revolutions: REPORT on Trade for Change: The EU Trade and Investment Strategy for the Southern Mediterranean following the Arab Spring revolutions
background: The 2010-2011 Arab Spring uprisings reshaped political dynamics in Southern Mediterranean states, prompting EU reassessment of its neighborhood policy under Article 8 TEU. Pre-existing economic disparities, limited regional integration, and prior EU trade frameworks like the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership faced challenges in addressing governance gaps and inclusive growth. The Parliament will discuss revising EU trade and investment approaches to align with democratic transitions, economic stabilization, and enhanced regional cooperation in the Southern Mediterranean.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the reliance on DCFTAs as fundamentally prioritizing EU agricultural conglomerates over local food sovereignty, exacerbating poverty through export-driven models.  
GREEN_EFA opposes bilateral trade negotiations as inconsistent with their demand for regional cooperation via the Agadir Framework to prevent fragmented economic dependencies.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding mechanisms to enforce human rights conditionality, risking continued marginalization of civil society in trade governance.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s failure to address how agricultural liberalization perpetuates social dumping, directly contradicting their stance on equitable development.  
This fundamentally againsts with GREEN_EFA’s position that trade agreements must require democratization benchmarks and grassroots participation to achieve meaningful justice.

ALDE strongly agrees the DCFTA framework as a catalyst for economic modernization and poverty reduction, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to integrating Mediterranean partners into value chains while upholding democratic conditionality.  
ALDE approves the SME-focused strategy but proposes amending Article 21 to mandate biannual progress reviews on micro-credit accessibility, ensuring alignment with ALDE's entrepreneurship priorities.  
ALDE applauds the visa facilitation provisions for businesspeople, which effectively advance ALDE's cross-border trade objectives while urging faster implementation timelines to match reform momentum.  
ALDE emphasizes enhancing the sustainable development chapter to include binding environmental safeguards, reflecting ALDE's principle that trade integration must parallel ecological modernization.  
ALDE endorses leveraging EIB/EBRD synergies for youth employment programs, directly supporting ALDE's vision of stabilizing the region through economic inclusion for under-25 populations.

SD strongly upholds the integration of human rights conditionality in DCFTAs, aligning with their commitment to democratic transitions and social justice.  
SD approves the focus on youth employment through ICT development, crucial given the region's demographic profile and EU's strategic interests.  
SD endorses agricultural modernization programs that align with EU standards, promoting sustainable rural economies and food security.  
SD highlights the need for comprehensive impact assessments to balance trade reciprocity, particularly in sensitive sectors like Mediterranean agriculture.  
SD welcomes enhanced EBRD involvement as vital for economic reforms that underpin lasting political stability in the region.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue's promotion of free trade agreements as fundamentally incompatible with their anti-imperialist principles and historical critique of EU economic policies.  
GUE/NGL opposes the DCFTA model for perpetuating neocolonial dependency through market deregulation that prioritizes multinational corporations over sovereign development.  
GUE/NGL condemns the "more for more" approach as a continuation of EU exploitation that substitutes genuine self-determination with extractive trade frameworks.  
GUE/NGL demands complete cancellation of odious debts inherited from dictatorships rather than conditional financial assistance through EIB/EBRD programs.  
GUE/NGL asserts that food sovereignty requires public ownership of resources and price controls, rejecting agricultural modernization tied to EU corporate standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised support for democratic transitions in Southern Mediterranean countries, emphasizing respect for human rights, peaceful assembly, and freedoms of expression, religion, and internet access. It endorsed tailored EU strategies, including Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) with Egypt, Jordan, Morocco, and Tunisia, tied to conditionality on human rights and mutual accountability. The resolution highlighted economic cooperation through investment frameworks, anti-corruption measures, and synergies with financial institutions like the EIB and EBRD, while stressing energy interconnections and sustainable development. It welcomed Tunisia’s democratic reforms as a regional model and advocated for agricultural modernization, noting that over a third of the workforce in Southern Mediterranean countries relies on agriculture. The EU was urged to support rural development via the European Neighbourhood Facility for Agriculture and Rural Development, aligning production with EU standards, promoting food security, and addressing climate challenges. The resolution called for balanced trade agreements to protect sensitive EU agricultural sectors, avoid social/environmental dumping, and foster youth and women’s inclusion in agriculture. It emphasized regulatory convergence in trade standards, infrastructure improvements, and global cooperation to mitigate food crises, underlining the link between inclusive growth, political stability, and prosperity in the region.

title: Trade between the Community and third countries in drug precursors: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 111/2005 laying down rules for the monitoring of trade between the Community and third countries in drug precursors
background: Existing EU regulations on monitoring drug precursor trade with third countries faced challenges in controlling diverted medicinal products containing ephedrine and pseudoephedrine, used in illicit methamphetamine production. The Parliament will discuss regulatory amendments to strengthen oversight of precursor substances while balancing legal trade needs and international obligations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the dynamic scheduling mechanism for updating controlled precursors, aligning with their commitment to adaptive anti-narcotics strategies.  
EPP applauds the targeted monitoring of ephedrine and pseudoephedrine trade, recognizing their critical role in disrupting methamphetamine production networks.  
EPP urges immediate operationalization of enhanced customs seizure protocols to counter large-scale diversion tactics by organized crime groups.  
EPP endorses harmonizing EU-wide controls with existing national restrictions, ensuring cohesive enforcement against pharmaceutical precursor exploitation.  
EPP commends the issue's proactive stance on emerging synthetic drug threats, reflecting EPP priorities for agile security frameworks.

EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on combating synthetic drug markets through stricter trade controls and international cooperation.  
EFD advises extending data retention periods for precursor trade records to prevent recidivism by convicted smugglers, proposing amendments to Article 6.  
EFD suggests enhancing company vetting procedures by mandating comprehensive background checks on firms engaged in precursor transactions.  
EFD recommends adding safeguards in Section 4 to reduce administrative burdens on businesses while ensuring data protection compliance.  
EFD highlights the necessity of binding mechanisms for cross-border law enforcement collaboration to strengthen monitoring effectiveness.

ALDE strongly accepts the issue’s enhanced monitoring framework for drug precursors, aligning with their commitment to combating organized crime and safeguarding public health through proactive EU measures.  
ALDE applauds the emphasis on updating the European database for registered operators, which reinforces transparency and cross-border cooperation to prevent diversion into illicit markets.  
ALDE proposes amending Article 2 to explicitly include medicinal products in the definition of scheduled substances, ensuring a forward-looking approach against traffickers’ evolving tactics.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of rapid information-sharing mechanisms on new precursor substitutes, urging the Commission to prioritize real-time data exchange between Member States.  
ALDE approves the issue’s recognition of shared responsibility in precursor control, underscoring the need for integrated policies spanning law enforcement, health, and regulatory sectors.

SD strongly endorses the enhanced customs controls on pseudoephedrine-containing medicines as a critical step to disrupt drug precursor trafficking, aligning with their commitment to combat organized crime and public health protection.  
SD applauds the creation of a dynamic category for future substances, recognizing this proactive mechanism as essential to address evolving synthetic drug production methods.  
SD proposes ensuring simplified procedures for legitimate trade by explicitly mandating cost-free licensing processes in Article 4 implementation guidelines, preserving accessibility while maintaining security.  
SD approves the issue’s balanced approach to monitoring, which strengthens EU external action against drug networks without unduly burdening consumers needing cold/allergy medications.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of swift codecision negotiations to operationalize these controls, reflecting their 2023 manifesto priority for agile EU responses to transnational crime.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s trade-related proposal (COM(2012)0521), grounded in Article 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and the legislative procedure under Article 294(2) and (3) TFEU. It adopted its first-reading stance based on the Committee on International Trade’s report (A7-0167/2013), urging the Commission to re-submit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or a replacement text are planned. The resolution further directed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with EU legislative processes and institutional cooperation.

title: Transitional arrangements for bilateral investment agreements between Member States and third countries: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing transitional arrangements for bilateral investment agreements between Member States and third countries
background: The 2009 Lisbon Treaty transferred foreign direct investment competence to the EU, affecting over 1,200 existing Member State bilateral agreements with third countries, which faced potential incompatibility under EU law. The Parliament will discuss transitional measures to align these agreements with the EU’s exclusive competence while maintaining legal certainty for international investors.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates establishing a common EU investment framework that preserves legal certainty for existing bilateral agreements while transitioning to unified standards.  
EPP approves the compromise maintaining over 1,000 Member State agreements as foundational for investor protection, aligning with their 2023 competitiveness agenda.  
EPP proposes clarifying Article 4 to limit Commission discretion in agreement reviews by specifying the four withdrawal criteria must involve treaty conflicts rather than policy preferences.  
EPP endorses defined transition periods as critical to prevent legal vacuums, reflecting their principle of incremental market integration without disruptive overhauls.  
EPP applauds the issue’s balance between national sovereignty in current deals and collective EU negotiation strength, advancing their vision of cohesive external economic diplomacy.

ALDE strongly promotes the transparency focus in bilateral investment agreements, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to open governance and investor confidence.  
ALDE approves the safeguards ensuring the Commission’s authority over non-compliant agreements while guaranteeing legal certainty for existing investments.  
ALDE applauds the pragmatic rejection of automatic repeal clauses for 1,200 agreements, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of balancing regulatory coherence with market stability.  
ALDE proposes preserving the committee-negotiated compromise during plenary votes to avoid destabilizing the balance between enforcement feasibility and investor protections.  
ALDE emphasizes the issue’s consistency with their 2011 trade policy goals, particularly in reinforcing EU competence without disrupting legitimate national economic interests.

SD rejects the regulation’s failure to codify a fixed transitional period for replacing bilateral agreements, directly conflicting with S&D’s insistence on legal certainty and phased EU competence consolidation.  
SD opposes the proposal’s deference to intergovernmental review mechanisms instead of mandating exclusive Commission oversight, undermining S&D’s demand for centralized EU authority to protect common interests.  
This fundamentally disputes with SD’s position that overlapping national investment agreements must be swiftly superseded by EU frameworks aligned with development policy priorities.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as enforceable timelines to prevent indefinite coexistence of conflicting regimes, contrary to S&D’s emphasis on Treaty-based EU exclusivity in investment policy.  
SD opposes fundamentally the lack of binding provisions to harmonize investor protections across Member States, perpetuating fragmentation S&D deems incompatible with EU unity.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to prioritize democratic accountability in bilateral investment agreements, firmly conflicting with their mandate for parliamentary sovereignty in trade policy.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposal's imbalance favoring financial and corporate interests over workers' rights, a core violation of their socialist principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the lack of enforceable safeguards against investor-state dispute mechanisms, inconsistent with their anti-neoliberal trade agenda.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding social clauses to protect labor standards, which GUE_NGL deems essential in any investment framework.  
This issue contradicts GUE_NGL's demand for transparent negotiation processes involving trade unions, cementing systemic opposition to corporate-dominated agreements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0344) concerning international trade matters under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It adopted its first-reading stance based on the Committee on International Trade’s report (A7-0148/2011) and the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or a replacement text are proposed. The resolution emphasized procedural adherence by instructing the Parliament’s President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with legislative processes while focusing on the proposal’s substantive trade-related objectives.

title: EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Japan for an Economic Partnership
background: The EU and Japan negotiated an Economic Partnership Agreement to strengthen bilateral trade ties amid global protectionist trends, addressing tariff reductions, market access, and sustainable development commitments. The Parliament will discuss ratification of the agreement and its alignment with EU trade policy objectives and international regulatory standards.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the EU-Japan EPA as a strategic victory for rules-based trade, eliminating 99% of tariffs while safeguarding EU agricultural interests through robust geographical indication protections.  
EPP absolutely accepts the agreement’s integration of sustainable development principles, particularly its binding commitment to uphold the Paris Climate Agreement and enforce high environmental standards.  
EPP applauds the dedicated SME chapter as a landmark achievement that will empower small businesses to access Japan’s $5 trillion market, aligning with the party’s 2023 priority of economic democratization.  
EPP proposes expanding the list of protected geographical indications in future reviews to include underrepresented EU regions, ensuring all member states benefit equitably from market access gains.  
EPP emphasizes the agreement’s geopolitical necessity in countering protectionist trends, with David McAllister noting it positions the EU as a "reliable global player" amid rising US-China trade tensions.

GREEN_EFA fully condemns the EPA's erosion of municipal democratic autonomy, as it mandates irreversible privatization of public services like water management and regional transport systems.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the agreement's constraints on environmental legislation, which prioritize trade convenience over binding commitments to prevent GMO proliferation and weaken climate crisis responses.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's failure to safeguard regulatory sovereignty, directly conflicting with the party's demand for unconditional rights to strengthen labor protections and banking sector reforms.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the agreement's corporate arbitration mechanisms as incompatible with their constitutional principle that public policy must supersede investor privileges.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the issue's claims about shared environmental values, noting Japan's continued whaling practices and lax chemical regulations remain unaddressed in monitoring provisions.

ECR completely endorses the EPA's strategic elevation of EU-Japan relations, perfectly aligning with the party's commitment to rules-based global trade and G20-level economic cooperation.  
ECR strongly accepts the immediate ratification timeline, recognizing the agreement's capacity to solidify Europe's trade leadership and counter protectionist narratives through enhanced market access.  
ECR applauds the binding environmental clauses as a model integration of climate governance with commercial policy, reflecting shared commitments to Paris Agreement implementation.  
ECR emphasizes the agreement's geostrategic value in counterbalancing regional security threats, particularly through reinforced economic ties that complement joint defense priorities.  
ECR commends the issue's safeguards for sensitive agricultural sectors and geographical indications, ensuring competitive fairness while advancing export opportunities.

GUE_NGL rejects the agreement’s failure to mandate Japan’s ratification of core ILO conventions, fully challengeing with their demand for binding labor protections in trade deals.  
GUE_NGL opposes the EPA’s tariff elimination framework for enabling agricultural dumping that accelerates the collapse of small Japanese farms, contradicting claims of "fair competition."  
GUE_NGL condemns the omission of enforceable EU data privacy standards in digital trade provisions, rendering the issue’s "regulatory cooperation" pledges hollow.  
GUE_NGL denounces the lack of concrete funding mechanisms for structural adjustments, exposing workers to job losses while corporations benefit from deregulated value chains.  
GUE_NGL rejects the reliance on voluntary environmental commitments that fail to penalize violations, directly undermining the Paris Agreement alignment touted in the issue.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) between the European Union and Japan (07965/2018), formally approving the comprehensive trade deal aimed at liberalizing bilateral trade and investment, eliminating tariffs on most goods, and addressing non-tariff barriers. The resolution endorsed the agreement’s provisions on sustainable development, including commitments to uphold the Paris Climate Agreement, promote labor rights, and enforce environmental standards, while safeguarding EU agricultural interests through protections for sensitive sectors and geographical indications. It emphasized the EPA’s potential to strengthen economic ties, increase market access for EU businesses, and reinforce shared values on fair competition and regulatory cooperation. The Parliament also called for effective implementation and monitoring of the agreement’s clauses, particularly regarding Japan’s adherence to international labor and environmental norms, and instructed its President to transmit the decision to the Council, Commission, and relevant national authorities to finalize ratification.

title: EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement (resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Japan for an Economic Partnership
background: The EU and Japan negotiated an Economic Partnership Agreement to deepen trade relations amid global protectionist trends, addressing tariff reductions, regulatory alignment, and market access while promoting shared standards in sustainability and labor rights. The Parliament will discuss ratification of the agreement and its strategic implications for bilateral economic cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the EPA’s tariff liberalization and SME provisions, aligning perfectly with their commitment to rules-based trade and economic resilience.
