It highlighted the 2015 ITUC affiliation of Uzbek trade unions and urged ratification of 27 GSP+ conventions to qualify for trade preferences. The EU pledged continued dialogue, aid for structural reforms, and scrutiny during Uzbekistan’s political transition following President Karimov’s death, stressing that deeper EU-Uzbek relations depend on sustained human rights and rule of law advancements.

title: Common Commercial Policy in the context of wildlife sustainability imperatives: REPORT on EU Common Commercial Policy in the context of wildlife sustainability imperatives
background: Escalating global wildlife trafficking linked to organized crime and biodiversity loss, alongside the EU’s role as a market and transit hub, prompted by international agreements like CITES and the UN 2030 Agenda, necessitated addressing unsustainable trade practices. The Parliament will discuss integrating wildlife sustainability imperatives into EU Common Commercial Policy.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the issue's integration of wildlife protection into trade policy, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to environmental stewardship and combatting transnational crime.  
EPP proposes expanding the scope to explicitly address illegal domestic pet trafficking networks, enhancing provisions on intra-EU wildlife crime beyond CITES-listed species.  
EPP approves the emphasis on EU collective action, urging enhanced customs coordination to leverage the Union's full market weight in sustainability negotiations.  
EPP endorses strict ivory trade bans and CITES enforcement as critical measures to disrupt trafficking syndicates consistent with EPP's 2023 biodiversity manifesto pledges.  
EPP highlights opportunities to strengthen public-private partnerships with veterinary associations and pet trade platforms to complement awareness campaigns against wildlife exploitation.

ENF strongly agrees the issue’s prioritization of combating wildlife trafficking as a security imperative, aligning perfectly with ENF's longstanding commitment to countering terrorism financing and organized crime.  
ENF approves the integration of sustainable development goals for African communities, ensuring economic stability alongside biodiversity preservation as outlined in UN SDG 15.  
ENF underscores the necessity of stringent anti-corruption measures in trade agreements, fully endorsing the issue’s alignment with UN conventions to dismantle transnational criminal networks.  
ENF proposes amending the issue to explicitly mandate reliance on existing EU legislation, such as the 2016 Action Plan, rather than introducing new regulatory frameworks.  
ENF advocates for targeted technical assistance to third countries’ customs authorities to strengthen governance without imposing undue burdens on local economies.

ALDE strongly accepts the issue’s integration of wildlife protection into EU trade policy, aligning with our commitment to sustainable development and biodiversity conservation.  
ALDE endorses the proposed EU-wide ban on elephant ivory trade as a critical measure to disrupt trafficking networks and set global standards.  
ALDE applauds the emphasis on CITES enforcement through trade agreements, which directly advances our priorities for multilateral environmental governance.  
ALDE proposes enhancing customs cooperation with third countries by allocating dedicated resources for wildlife-specific training programs.  
ALDE highlights the need for expanded monitoring of online platforms to address emerging digital trafficking channels while maintaining WTO compliance.

SD strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on integrating anti-corruption clauses in trade agreements, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to governance transparency and disrupting illicit supply chains.  
SD approves the prioritization of capacity-building funds for customs authorities and local producer cooperatives, which directly advances sustainable livelihoods as a counterweight to illegal wildlife economies.  
SD endorses expanding enforcement efforts to address aquatic wildlife trafficking, particularly coral and sturgeon products, to close jurisdictional gaps in current EU action plans.  
SD proposes establishing a European-level recognition mechanism for anti-trafficking champions to incentivize grassroots innovation and cross-border collaboration.  
SD fully aligns with leveraging WTO-CITES technical cooperation to eliminate harmful fisheries subsidies, reinforcing multilateral frameworks for resource sustainability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns about the unprecedented surge in wildlife trafficking, which threatens biodiversity, fuels conflicts, and generates up to €20 billion annually, ranking as the fourth most profitable illegal activity. It emphasized the EU’s role as a major market, transit hub, and source for illegal wildlife products, stressing the need for integrated action targeting both supply and demand, including online platforms. The resolution endorsed the EU’s 2016 Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking to strengthen enforcement, curb corruption, and enhance customs cooperation, while advocating for robust provisions in trade agreements, such as the EU-Vietnam FTA, to enforce multilateral environmental agreements like CITES. It highlighted WTO exceptions under GATT Articles XX(a) and (g) to protect public morals and exhaustible resources, aligning with UN Sustainable Development Goal 15 to combat poaching and trafficking. The Parliament called for an EU-wide ban on elephant ivory trade, including pre-Convention ivory, compliant with WTO rules, and urged capacity-building for third countries’ customs and governance. It stressed collaboration with NGOs, the private sector, and international bodies to disrupt criminal networks, promote corporate responsibility, and reduce demand through awareness campaigns. Additionally, it advocated for anti-corruption measures in trade deals, technical assistance via WTO-CITES cooperation, and dissuasive penalties under the UN Convention against Transnational Organized Crime to dismantle trafficking syndicates.

title: Conclusion of the EU-Canada CETA-Motions for resolutions: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the conclusion of the EU-Canada CETA
background: The EU and Canada negotiated the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) over seven years, facing legal questions over its compatibility with EU treaties, uncertainties regarding joint declarations, and public opposition to traditional trade models. The Parliament will discuss ratifying CETA, addressing legal-institutional coherence, regulatory cooperation mechanisms, and socio-economic implications for member states.

stances.stance:
EPP fully agrees CETA as it perfectly aligns with their commitment to job creation and economic growth through strategic international partnerships, citing the 55% export increase and 14 000 new jobs from the EU-South Korea agreement as precedent.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on setting global trade standards, emphasizing that CETA establishes rules-based globalization to protect EU interests against protectionist agendas like those advocated by nationalist factions.  
EPP fully agrees the agreement's protection of SMEs and environmental standards, highlighting provisions that maintain high EU regulations while expanding market access for 900 000 export-dependent businesses.  
EPP perfectly aligns with CETA's role in reinforcing EU-Canada shared democratic values, ensuring mutual recognition of professional qualifications and enhanced public procurement opportunities across provincial and municipal levels.  
EPP fully agrees the modernization of dispute issue through the Investment Court System, viewing it as a progressive improvement over existing mechanisms that upholds legal certainty and investor fairness.

EFDD rejects the CETA agreement as a covert institutional reform undermining democratic governance, citing the creation of unelected technocratic bodies with unchecked authority over treaty interpretation.  
EFDD opposes fundamentally the Investor Court System (ICS) for prioritizing corporate interests over public welfare, enabling foreign investors to bypass domestic legal systems and challenge sovereign regulations.  
EFDD condemns the Regulatory Cooperation chapter for subordinating public health and environmental standards to economic interests, particularly highlighting risks of GMO infiltration and weakened food safety protections aligned with Codex Alimentarius.  
EFDD challenges CETA's threat to public services through irreversible privatization mechanisms, emphasizing the Negative List approach and standstill clauses that lock in deregulation of water, healthcare, and essential utilities.  
 EFDD member Petr Mach's support for tariff elimination contradicts the group's majority opposition, reflecting internal discord on trade liberalization principles.

GREEN_EFA rejects the Investment Court System as fundamentally undemocratic, directly conflicting with their principle that corporate tribunals must never supersede public courts.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the environmental provisions for enshrining weaker Codex Alimentarius standards instead of the Precautionary Principle, failing to address Canada's active promotion of tar sands exports.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the Negative List approach to public services as incompatible with their manifesto commitment to shield essential utilities from privatization pressures.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's failure to mandate enforceable ILO labor standards, contradicting their core demand for trade justice frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the ratification process for cementing corporate capture of legislation, inconsistent with their democratic governance priorities given the documented lobbyist access during negotiations.

ALDE strongly accepts the conclusion of CETA as a strategic advancement of EU-Canada relations, aligning with their commitment to open markets and multilateralism in the face of global protectionist trends.  
ALDE applauds the modernized Investment Court System as a transformative model that replaces outdated arbitration mechanisms, ensuring transparency while maintaining investor confidence.  
ALDE emphasizes CETA's unprecedented SME provisions, particularly streamlined customs procedures and access to Canadian provincial procurement markets, which democratize trade opportunities.  
ALDE highlights the agreement's reinforcement of shared democratic values and environmental standards, countering misinformation about deregulation risks through binding labor and climate commitments.  
ALDE proposes periodic reviews of SME utilization metrics to optimize support structures, ensuring smaller enterprises fully benefit from tariff eliminations and regulatory harmonization.

resolution: The European Parliament raised significant concerns about the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with Canada, declining consent due to substantive risks to democracy, public welfare, social standards, agriculture, and industrial policy. Key objections included the Investment Court System (ICS), which prioritizes foreign investor rights over public interest by allowing claims without exhausting domestic legal remedies, and the Regulatory Cooperation chapter, which subordinates legislation to economic necessity, risking deregulation. Environmental safeguards were deemed inadequate, citing Canada’s history of challenging EU laws (e.g., REACH, pesticides) and CETA’s failure to enshrine the Precautionary Principle, instead aligning with weaker standards like the Codex Alimentarius. The agreement’s promotion of GMO harmonization and fossil fuel imports from Canadian tar sands (undermining the EU’s Fuel Quality Directive) further threatened climate goals. Public services faced risks due to a Negative List approach with standstill and ratchet clauses, constraining future policy flexibility. Social impacts included projected long-term unemployment and inequality, as 2011 assessments indicated redistribution favoring capital owners, while labor provisions lacked enforceable ILO core standards. Agricultural liberalization risked small-scale farmers and animal welfare, with no binding animal welfare rules. Industrial policy concerns centered on prohibitions against local content requirements, hindering green transitions, and inadequate SME support, noting 1% of exporters (large firms) dominate over half of export value. Procurement rules were criticized for cementing restrictive frameworks, limiting green infrastructure investments. Legal uncertainties persisted, including compatibility with EU Treaties, unresolved CJEU opinions (e.g., pending Belgian request), and contradictory declarations, undermining democratic oversight. The resolution concluded CETA endangered sustainable, equitable development and democratic governance.

title: Control of exports, transfer, brokering, technical assistance and transit of dual-use items: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council setting up a Union regime for the control of exports, transfer, brokering, technical assistance and transit of dual-use items (recast)
background: Reports of EU-origin surveillance technologies used in human rights violations by authoritarian regimes, rapid advancements in cyber-surveillance tools, and gaps in existing export controls prompted calls to address regulatory weaknesses. The Parliament will discuss updating the EU’s dual-use export control regime to balance trade, security, and human rights protections.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely endorses the modernization of dual-use export controls as perfectly aligning with its commitment to global security and human rights protection.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's focus on preventing authoritarian misuse of surveillance technologies through enhanced IT sector accountability.  
EPP absolutely endorses the compromise framework for balancing economic competitiveness with ethical trade practices in critical technologies.  
EPP emphasizes that the regulation's updated technical definitions effectively address evolving cyber-surveillance risks while maintaining export viability.  
EPP applauds the issue's harmonization of trade facilitation and human rights safeguards as advancing Europe's geopolitical leadership.

EFDD conditionally endorses the recast regulation but demands amendments to Article 12 to explicitly prohibit transshipment through third countries like Turkey, citing documented evasion cases raised in Al Jazeera investigations.  
EFDD requests revising Annex II to include real-time tracking requirements for dual-use technologies, preventing misuse by authoritarian regimes as highlighted in recent surveillance tool diversion cases.  
The proposal entirely challenges with EFDD's stance on corporate accountability by failing to mandate human rights impact assessments for all brokering licenses under Chapter IV.  
EFDD urges binding provisions requiring member states to prosecute companies circumventing controls, referencing evidence of Italian firms exploiting jurisdictional gaps to supply conflict zones.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of end-user verification, maintaining a self-certification system EFDD deems inadequate to prevent surveillance tech reaching repressive governments.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the enhanced export controls as a critical step to prevent surveillance technologies from enabling authoritarian repression, aligning with their human rights advocacy.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s focus on learning from the Arab Spring’s lessons, particularly in prohibiting indirect complicity through dual-use exports to high-risk regimes.  
GREEN_EFA proposes expanding real-time monitoring of export licenses to address historical gaps revealed by cases like Swedish equipment reaching Gaddafi’s Libya.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the cross-party consensus as vital to ensure European technologies empower democratic movements rather than endanger activists.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that swift implementation of Articles 4-7 will operationalize their manifesto goal of "ethical trade architectures" in sensitive sectors.

GUE_NGL strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on binding human rights due diligence for dual-use exports, aligning perfectly with their commitment to preventing complicity in repression.  
GUE_NGL applauds the proposed framework for stricter oversight of technology transfers as a critical step to halt corporate facilitation of surveillance abuses like those documented in Bahrain.  
GUE_NGL urges reinforcing Article 6 to mandate proactive human rights impact assessments before approving exports to high-risk states, enhancing enforcement coherence.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes that swift implementation with robust parliamentary oversight is essential to close loopholes exploited by authoritarian regimes through European technologies.  
GUE_NGL approves the trialogue mandate while insisting member states allocate dedicated resources for monitoring corporate compliance with ethical trade principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2016 proposal (COM(2016)0616) to codify existing trade-related legislation, emphasizing that the Consultative Working Party of the EU legal services confirmed the proposal contained no substantive amendments beyond those explicitly identified, thereby preserving the original legal framework without altering its substance. The resolution endorsed the Parliament’s first-reading position, aligning with the Working Party’s findings, and urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if future substantial changes or amendments were introduced. It further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring transparency and adherence to procedural requirements under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

title: Agreement between the EU, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway on an EEA Financial Mechanism 2014-2021: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union, Iceland, the Principality of Liechtenstein and the Kingdom of Norway on an EEA Financial Mechanism 2014-2021, the Agreement between the Kingdom of Norway and the European Union on a Norwegian Financial Mechanism for the period 2014-2021, the Additional Protocol to the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Kingdom of Norway, and the Additional Protocol to the Agreement between the European Economic Community and Iceland
background: The European Union, Iceland, Liechtenstein, and Norway negotiated renewed EEA financial mechanisms (2014-2021) following expiring 2004-2014 agreements, alongside bilateral protocols on fisheries. Norway’s 2013 unilateral tariff increases on EU agricultural products created trade tensions. The Parliament will discuss approving the agreements and addressing related trade concerns.

stances.stance:
EFDD conditionally endorses the financial mechanisms but requests revisions to Article 3 to include annual independent audits of contribution allocations, citing Norway's tenfold cost increase since 1992 as unsustainable without transparent oversight.  
EFDD objects to the lack of sunset clauses for automatic contribution renewals, arguing this mirrors undemocratic EU structures and conflicts with EFDD's principles of national sovereignty and fiscal accountability.  
EFDD highlights the issue's failure to address public discontent in Norway, proposing mandatory national referendums before extending financial commitments beyond 2021 to align with democratic governance standards.  
EFDD questions the proportionality of Norway's 94% contribution share, urging renegotiation clauses to reflect actual single market benefits received by EU members and prevent asymmetric financial burdens.  
EFDD warns against replicating Norway's model in post-Brexit UK agreements, noting the issue's approach completely againsts with EFDD's opposition to supranational financial obligations lacking direct voter approval mechanisms.

ALDE fundamentally accepts the issue as it perfectly aligns with their commitment to deepening single market integration and reducing economic disparities through structured financial cooperation.  
ALDE highlights the EEA Financial Mechanism’s role in advancing innovation and social inclusion, core priorities outlined in their 2014-2021 policy agenda.  
ALDE urges enhanced future negotiations on agricultural trade liberalization, framing stalled progress as an opportunity to strengthen mutual trust and market access.  
ALDE commends Norway’s disproportionate financial contribution while proposing intensified dialogue to align tariff policies with single market principles.  
ALDE emphasizes that swift issue of non-tariff barriers would amplify the mechanisms’ cohesion objectives, ensuring full reciprocity in EEA partnerships.

SD fully accepts the EEA Financial Mechanism's targeted allocation of €2.8 billion to reduce economic disparities, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to social cohesion and youth employment prioritization.  
SD proposes strengthening enforcement mechanisms to ensure Norway's tariff practices fully comply with single market principles, enhancing agricultural trade fairness while maintaining the agreement's cooperative spirit.  
SD applauds the issue's focus on climate action and green job creation through the Norwegian Financial Mechanism, which directly advances SD's 2021-2024 sustainability agenda.  
SD emphasizes the critical need to formalize Svalbard Treaty compliance within bilateral protocols to safeguard equitable fisheries access and environmental stewardship.  
SD perfectly aligns with the expanded eligibility criteria allowing high-youth-unemployment states to access funds, effectively advancing SD's decade-long campaign against intergenerational inequality.

GUE_NGL supports the issue's emphasis on reducing economic disparities through Norway's substantial financial contributions, aligning with their commitment to European solidarity and social cohesion.  
GUE_NGL advises strengthening safeguards for Norwegian farmers and fishers in agricultural trade provisions to reflect their unique geographic challenges, ensuring agreements do not undermine local livelihoods.  
GUE_NGL highlights the necessity of ongoing dialogue on tariff adjustments, urging transparency in future negotiations to balance market access with equitable outcomes.  
GUE_NGL acknowledges the updated protocols' institutional improvements but cautions against over-liberalization in sectors critical to partner states' economies.  
GUE_NGL stresses that continued cooperation must prioritize poverty reduction and climate action while respecting non-EU states' rights to protect vulnerable industries.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval for the conclusion of four key agreements and protocols to strengthen financial and institutional cooperation with Iceland, Liechtenstein, and Norway. These include the 2014-2021 EEA Financial Mechanism, through which Norway, Iceland, and Liechtenstein will collectively contribute €2.8 billion (with Norway providing 94%, Iceland 5%, and Liechtenstein 1%) to reduce economic and social disparities in the EEA, and the separate Norwegian Financial Mechanism, under which Norway will allocate an additional €1.1 billion to support EU priorities such as innovation, climate action, and social inclusion. The resolution also endorsed two Additional Protocols updating the existing bilateral agreements between the EU and Norway and Iceland, respectively, to align them with evolving legal and policy frameworks. The agreements, initially finalized on 17 July 2015, aim to deepen cooperation in the single market, enhance institutional governance, and ensure the effective implementation of financial contributions. The Parliament emphasized the mechanisms’ role in fostering cohesion and shared objectives across the EEA, while instructing its leadership to formally communicate the decision to relevant EU institutions and the governments and parliaments of the participating states.

title: Customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 374/2014 on the reduction or elimination of customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine
background: The EU granted Ukraine unilateral trade preferences in 2014 to support its economy during territorial conflicts and trade disruptions with neighboring states, alongside postponed implementation of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement’s trade provisions. The Parliament will discuss extending customs duty reductions on Ukrainian goods to align with ongoing geopolitical and institutional timelines.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the provisional trade measures as a vital demonstration of EU credibility, aligning perfectly with commitments to counter external aggression and stabilize Ukraine.  
EPP proposes implementing a mandatory six-month impact assessment to monitor economic effects while fully endorsing the 14-month exceptional timeframe.  
EPP approves the issue’s geopolitical alignment, viewing accelerated trade integration as essential for reinforcing European unity and Ukrainian sovereignty.  
EPP emphasizes parallel structural reforms in Ukraine’s governance and economy as critical prerequisites for sustained EU trade cooperation beyond 2015.  
EPP endorses the Council’s adherence to legislative timelines, ensuring the measures remain a temporary instrument without undermining EU market stability.

EFDD absolutely disputes with the issue's unilateral tariff preferences that impose €487 million in budgetary burdens without reciprocal benefits for EU agricultural sectors.  
EFDD rejects the measure's failure to address contamination risks from Ukrainian exports, particularly GMO flours and products bypassing EU phytosanitary standards.  
EFDD opposes the economic sacrifice imposed on maize and flour producers facing over 60% Ukrainian export dominance under reduced tariffs.  
EFDD highlights the proposal's disregard for farmers already impacted by the August 2014 Russian embargo, compounding market destabilization.  
EFDD demands binding commitments on Association Agreement ratification timelines rather than open-ended concessions harming EU producers.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue’s allocation of up to €500 million in aid to Ukraine, aligning perfectly with their commitment to Eastern Partnership solidarity and economic resilience.  
GREEN_EFA approves the urgency of adopting the issue to counter Russian coercion and uphold Ukraine’s sovereignty, reflecting their prioritization of geopolitical stability in Eastern Europe.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s strategic value in advancing Ukraine’s integration into EU processes, effectively matching their manifesto goals for equitable trade partnerships.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the “fishing rod, not fish” approach as critical for sustainable economic development, a principle central to their advocacy for self-reliant growth models.  
GREEN_EFA commends the procedural adherence to legislative oversight, ensuring alignment with democratic values while maintaining swift support for Ukraine.

GUE/NGL rejects the proposal as it fundamentally rejects with principles of equitable economic cooperation by setting export quotas that exploit Ukraine's current vulnerabilities rather than ensuring sustainable development.  
GUE/NGL opposes the regulation’s failure to address human rights violations and fascist militias in Ukraine, which directly contradicts the party’s commitment to anti-imperialism and democratic sovereignty.  
GUE/NGL condemns the hypocritical allowance of animal products from Ukrainian battery farms, undermining EU animal welfare standards and prioritizing trade expansion over ethical consistency.  
GUE/NGL highlights the proposal’s disregard for peaceful conflict issue, as it neglects trilateral negotiations with Russia and exacerbates geopolitical tensions instead of fostering dialogue.  
GUE/NGL denounces the neoliberal imposition of market liberalization, which dismantles Ukraine’s productive capacity and entrenches dependency on EU corporate interests.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the 2014 Commission proposal (COM(2014)0597) concerning trade-related measures under Article 207(2) of the TFEU, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in document A8-0021/2014. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts to the original proposal, ensuring legislative oversight. The resolution highlighted the Council’s prior commitment (16 October 2014) to endorse Parliament’s position under Article 294(4) TFEU and instructed its President to formally transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence while focusing on maintaining alignment in the legislative process.

title: Modernisation of the trade pillar of the EU-Chile Association Agreement: REPORT on a European Parliament recommendation to the Council, the Commission and the European External Action Service on the negotiations of the modernisation of the trade pillar of the EU-Chile Association Agreement
background: The EU-Chile Association Agreement, established in 2002, facilitated significant trade growth but lacked provisions on modern priorities like sustainable development, digital trade, and gender equality. Both parties pursued updated agreements with other partners, while Chile emerged as a key Latin American OECD member. The Parliament will discuss modernizing the trade framework to align with contemporary economic and regulatory standards.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the issue’s failure to explicitly denounce the EU’s misleading narrative that free movement is a precondition for trade agreements, contradicting EFDD’s evidence-based trade principles.  
The proposal completely opposes with EFDD’s stance by ignoring the need to codify the absence of free movement clauses, despite their proven irrelevance in 99% of EU trade deals.  
EFDD opposes the modernization’s alignment with broader EU practices that perpetuate manipulative claims, undermining trust in trade policy transparency.  
The issue overlooks EFDD’s demand to formally clarify in the agreement’s text that free movement of people is not required, countering systemic EU misinformation.  
EFDD slightly promotes tariff reforms but insists on binding provisions to prevent future linkage of trade and free movement, reflecting Chile’s existing terms.

ALDE totally endorses the modernization of the EU-Chile Association Agreement to address modern trade challenges, emphasizing expanded market access in services, digital commerce, and non-tariff barriers. This aligns perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to advancing open, rules-based trade with strategic partners.  

ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s call for new chapters on investment protection and SMEs, which will foster innovation and cross-border entrepreneurship. The proposal effectively advances ALDE's priority of creating predictable frameworks for businesses while replacing outdated ISDS mechanisms.  

ALDE strongly agrees the inclusion of binding environmental commitments tied to the Paris Agreement, reflecting shared ambitions for climate action. The issue’s integration of renewable energy cooperation mirrors ALDE’s vision of aligning trade policy with ecological transition goals.  

ALDE applauds the emphasis on enforceable labor standards, particularly the alignment with ILO Convention No. 169 on indigenous rights, which reinforces core values of social equity. This resonates with ALDE’s principles of embedding human rights protections in trade agreements.  

ALDE urges accelerated negotiations to finalize the modernized agreement, stressing Chile’s role as a key ally in countering protectionism. The issue’s timeline for concluding talks aligns with ALDE’s proactive approach to securing timely, high-ambition trade outcomes.

SD strongly upholds the inclusion of binding gender equality provisions, particularly the mandate for data disaggregation and support for women-led SMEs, which aligns perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to intersectional social justice and economic inclusivity.  
SD approves the enforceable labor standards tied to ILO conventions, including indigenous rights under Convention No. 169, as this effectively advances SD’s priority of safeguarding marginalized communities in trade frameworks.  
SD applauds the integration of the Paris Agreement into environmental protections, emphasizing that this modernization mirrors SD’s 2023 manifesto pledge to embed climate action in all EU external agreements.  
SD proposes clarifying the Joint Consultative Committee’s role to explicitly include quarterly civil society audits, enhancing transparency without opposing the issue’s core accountability mechanisms.  
SD highlights the strategic importance of replacing ISDS with a public Investment Court System, calling this reform critical to aligning the agreement with SD’s principles of democratic governance and public interest prioritization.

GUE_NGL rejects the inclusion of the Investment Court System (ICS) as a repackaged ISDS mechanism, firmly rejecting with their opposition to privileging corporate interests over democratic sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL opposes the reliance on investor tribunals instead of ordinary judicial systems, which undermines constitutional frameworks and perpetuates corporate impunity.  
GUE_NGL criticizes the mutual recognition of bio-product standards as a failure to establish common high benchmarks, risking environmental and consumer protections.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s failure to mandate binding sanctions for labor and environmental violations, contradicting their demand for enforceable accountability.  
GUE_NGL acknowledges the gender chapter’s novelty but deems it insufficient to offset the unacceptable concessions to investor power structures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to modernize the 2002 EU-Chile Association Agreement (AA) to reflect evolving economic, social, and environmental priorities, emphasizing enhanced trade, sustainable development, and shared values. It highlighted that bilateral trade in goods reached €8.6 billion (EU exports) and €7.4 billion (Chilean exports) in 2016, with EU foreign direct investment stocks in Chile at €42.8 billion, but noted gaps in the original AA, such as lacking chapters on investment, SMEs, gender, energy, and enforceable labor and environmental standards. The resolution called for a modernized AA to include binding commitments on labor rights (aligning with ILO conventions, including indigenous rights under Convention No. 169), environmental protections (notably the Paris Agreement), gender equality (with data disaggregation and support for women-led SMEs), and anti-corruption measures. It urged replacing outdated bilateral investment treaties with a reformed investment chapter prioritizing public interest regulation, replacing ISDS with a public Investment Court System (ICS), and ensuring tax transparency to combat evasion. Market access improvements were recommended, including tariff reductions, simplified rules of origin, and safeguards for sensitive sectors, alongside provisions to protect public services, cultural diversity, and data privacy. The resolution stressed the inclusion of a robust Trade and Sustainable Development Chapter (TSDC) with enforceable dispute mechanisms, cooperation on renewable energy, and commitments to animal welfare. It demanded transparency, civil society involvement via the Joint Consultative Committee, and parliamentary oversight, while ensuring separate agreements for EU-exclusive and shared competences post-Court of Justice guidance. The modernization aims to balance economic gains with social equity, environmental stewardship, and respect for human rights, aligning with Chile’s role as a strategic partner in multilateral governance.

title: Implementation of the EU-Colombia and Peru Trade Agreement: REPORT on the implementation of the Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru
background: The EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement, provisionally applied since 2013, established market liberalization and sustainability commitments alongside Colombia’s 2016 peace accord, Ecuador’s 2017 accession, and Venezuelan migration impacts. The Parliament will discuss implementation progress, trade dynamics, and compliance with labor, environmental, and human rights obligations under the agreement.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to activate human rights enforcement mechanisms despite systematic killings of activists in Colombia, entirely disputeing with their mandate for rights-based trade.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the omission of Panama's tax haven status in Central American provisions, overlooking critical aspects of financial corruption that enable environmental and labor exploitation.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the joint debate structure as incompatible with rigorous scrutiny of human rights impacts, violating their principle of granular accountability in trade governance.  
GREEN_EFA highlights unresolved complaints from Peruvian unions about eroded environmental standards under the Agreement, demanding immediate suspension until compliance audits occur.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the Commission's post-implementation monitoring approach as inadequate, citing systemic violence against women informal workers left unaddressed by current labor provisions.

SD strongly advocates the Agreement’s strategic role in advancing socio-economic development and regional integration, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to multilateralism and sustainable governance. The emphasis on civil society participation through Domestic Advisory Groups is hailed as vital for ensuring transparency.  

SD applauds the prioritization of SME integration, particularly the 328 Colombian and 90% Peruvian SMEs accessing EU markets, and urges expanded technical cooperation to amplify their competitiveness in line with SD’s economic justice agenda.  

SD emphasizes the critical need for binding sanctions mechanisms to enforce sustainability clauses, noting that gaps in labor rights protections—such as low unionization and violence against activists—require immediate redress to align with SD’s human rights mandates.  

SD welcomes Ecuador’s accession as a step toward broader Andean integration and stresses the issue’s call to diversify exports beyond raw materials, proposing EU-funded value-addition initiatives to advance equitable trade.

ECR strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on environmental protection and Paris Agreement alignment, which aligns with their commitment to enforcing ecological standards in trade partnerships.  
ECR applauds the focus on human rights and labor rights reforms, particularly measures to address violence against activists and informal employment, reflecting their prioritization of social justice in trade policy.  
ECR approves the safeguards for indigenous populations through land reform initiatives but proposes enhancing the Agreement with explicit clauses to prevent land dispossession by multinational corporations.  
ECR endorses the integration of gender equality provisions into the Agreement’s revision, urging targeted technical cooperation programs for women-led SMEs to advance inclusive economic growth.  
ECR acknowledges the issue’s balanced approach to monitoring EU agricultural exports’ impact on local markets, ensuring fair competition while stabilizing partner economies.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s silence on Colombia’s escalating political violence, including the 2019 murders of activists, which entirely challenges with their mandate to prioritize human rights over trade liberalization.  
GUE_NGL opposes the agreement’s extractivist economic model, noting that 70% raw material exports deepen dependency and contradict their principles of equitable development and environmental justice.  
GUE_NGL condemns the exclusion of binding mechanisms to address labor informality and gender disparities, overlooking critical aspects like women’s precarious employment and union repression in Peru.  
GUE_NGL demands suspension of the agreement until land reforms and Indigenous protections are enforced, citing Brazil’s Bolsonaro-era threats as proof of regional democratic backsliding incompatible with EU values.  
GUE_NGL rejects the prioritization of corporate access over civil society engagement, noting Domestic Advisory Groups’ marginalization as emblematic of neoliberal trade policy antithetical to participatory governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the strategic importance of the EU Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru, emphasizing its role in fostering socio-economic development, regional integration, and adherence to human rights, labor, and environmental standards. It highlighted the Agreement’s potential to support Colombia’s peace process, including land reform and economic diversification in conflict-affected regions, while noting Ecuador’s accession as a step toward deeper regional integration. Despite a decline in trade flows post-implementation, the Agreement stabilized economies amid global challenges, with EU investment stocks rising and 1,155 Colombian (328 SMEs) and 2,328 Peruvian (90% SMEs) companies beginning exports to the EU. Concerns were raised over export reliance on raw materials (70% of Colombia and Peru’s exports), urging diversification toward value-added goods. The resolution called for enhanced SME support, improved awareness of Agreement benefits, and resolution of trade irritants like certification barriers and discriminatory taxes. It stressed the need to address labor rights gaps, including low unionization, violence against activists, and informal employment (notably affecting women), while welcoming Colombia’s OECD accession and Peru’s reforms. Environmental commitments, including Paris Agreement alignment, and anti-corruption measures were underscored, alongside calls to revise the Agreement with chapters on gender, SMEs, and a dispute mechanism for sustainability violations. The resolution urged monitoring of EU agricultural exports’ impact on local markets, compliance with banana import thresholds, and technical cooperation to meet EU food safety standards. It reiterated support for multilateral trade systems, WTO modernization, and civil society engagement through Domestic Advisory Groups to ensure transparency and accountability.

title: Implementation of the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement: REPORT on the implementation of the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Korea
background: The EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement, in force since 2015, aimed to eliminate tariffs and non-tariff barriers across goods, services, and intellectual property. By 2016, bilateral trade growth reversed the EU’s deficit to a surplus, though concerns persisted regarding labor standards, technical barriers, and regulatory compliance. The Parliament will discuss the agreement’s implementation, economic effects, and adherence to sustainable development commitments.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the transformative economic outcomes of the EU-Korea FTA, particularly the reversal of the trade deficit into a €2.5 billion surplus, which aligns perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to fostering competitive global markets and job creation.  
EPP applauds the elimination of tariffs and expanded services access as instrumental in advancing EPP’s priority of reinforcing Europe’s trade leadership, while proposing accelerated technical committee reviews to resolve homologation disputes for automotive exports.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need to enhance SME awareness programs, urging the Commission to integrate FTA utilization guides into the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs initiative to maximize untapped €900 million export potential.  
EPP underscores the urgency of formal consultations under Article 13.14 to address Korea’s ratification gaps in ILO conventions, framing labor rights enforcement as a strategic enhancement opportunity rather than a critique.  
EPP advocates stricter monitoring of sanitary and geographical indication barriers affecting agricultural exports, ensuring the agreement’s sustainability chapter reflects EU standards without opposing its foundational success.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to address systemic exploitation of migrant workers in Korea, entirely disputeing with their core principle of universal labor protections.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the continued tolerance of investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) mechanisms, demanding complete elimination rather than partial reform as outlined in their amendments.  
The proposal overlooks critical democratic deficits by maintaining corporate arbitration privileges that bypass national judicial systems and workers' redress mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's disproportionate focus on tariff elimination while inadequately sanctioning Korea's imprisonment of union leaders under ILO Convention 87 violations.  
This framework contradicts GREEN_EFA's environmental justice mandate by prioritizing trade growth metrics over enforceable climate commitments in cross-border supply chains.

SD strongly approves the issue's validation of the FTA's economic achievements, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to trade policies that reverse deficits and foster sectoral growth.  
SD strongly endorses invoking Article 13.14 dispute mechanisms to address Korea's failure to ratify ILO conventions, reflecting SD's non-negotiable prioritization of labor rights in trade frameworks.  
SD approves the emphasis on rectifying uneven tariff utilization through compliance measures, directly advancing SD's goal of equitable agreement implementation for SMEs and exporters.  
SD proposes amending the Sustainable Development Chapter to include binding sanctions for labor rights violations, ensuring Korea releases imprisoned union leaders and aligns with ILO standards.  
SD applauds the issue's push to replace ISDS with a public Investment Court System, perfectly matching SD's manifesto commitment to democratize dispute issue.

GUE/NGL rejects the FTA's economic model that reversed trade deficits to Korea's detriment, violating principles of equitable partnership.  
GUE/NGL opposes the failure to suspend agreements despite South Korea's systemic labor rights abuses, including 15,000 annual worker suicides linked to exploitative conditions.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's silence on environmental harm, noting the FTA's documented increase in CO₂ emissions and pollution.  
GUE/NGL demands immediate formal consultations under Article 13.14 to address non-ratification of ILO conventions and state repression of unions.  
GUE/NGL firmly condemns ISDS frameworks, advocating replacement with binding human rights obligations for corporations rather than procedural reforms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the significant economic benefits of the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement (FTA), noting that it transformed the EU’s pre-FTA trade deficit of €7.6 billion into a surplus of €2.5 billion by its fifth year, with EU exports to Korea growing by 47% to €44.9 billion and imports from Korea rising by 11% to €42.3 billion. Key sectors like automotive trade saw EU vehicle exports surge by 246% (€6.9 billion) and imports increase by 71% (€4.5 billion), while services trade reached a €6 billion surplus. The agreement eliminated nearly all tariffs, expanded market access in services, investment, and public procurement, and established committees to address non-tariff barriers, though issues persisted, including technical barriers (e.g., restrictive transport clauses, vehicle homologation disputes), sanitary barriers on EU agricultural exports, and insufficient protection of labor rights. Parliament criticized Korea’s failure to ratify core ILO conventions, citing violations of union freedoms and imprisonment of labor leaders, and urged formal consultations under Article 13.14 of the FTA. It highlighted uneven preference utilization rates (68.5% for EU vs. 85% for Korea), stressing potential gains of €900 million for EU exporters through improved compliance. SMEs’ low awareness of FTA benefits was flagged, alongside calls to replace ISDS with a new Investment Court System. Parliament emphasized the FTA’s strategic role in EU-Asia relations and urged stronger enforcement of sustainable development commitments, including labor and environmental standards, while advocating for multilateral cooperation on trade in services and environmental goods.

title: Evaluation of external aspects of customs performance and management as a tool to facilitate trade and fight illicit trade: REPORT on the evaluation of external aspects of the customs performance and management as a tool to facilitate trade and fight illicit trade
background: The EU Customs Union, a cornerstone of regional trade integration, faced operational challenges including uneven implementation of the 2016 Union Customs Code, disparities in member states’ customs controls, rising illicit trade volumes, and evolving risks from e-commerce and transnational crime. The Parliament will discuss optimizing customs frameworks to strengthen trade facilitation and counter illicit practices.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the harmonization of customs procedures across Member States, aligning with the issue's call for uniform enforcement to eliminate trade distortions and revenue losses. This aligns perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to a level playing field for EU ports and businesses.  
EPP approves the issue's emphasis on enhanced cooperation with OLAF and international partners, proposing strengthened knowledge-sharing mechanisms between customs authorities and law enforcement agencies to combat cross-border fraud more effectively.  
EPP endorses the full implementation of the Union Customs Code and Smart and Secure Trade Lanes initiative, highlighting the need for accelerated IT system modernization to achieve paperless customs while maintaining rigorous anti-counterfeiting measures.  
EPP applauds the focus on Authorized Economic Operator programs as critical for trade facilitation, suggesting additional simplification of certification processes to reduce bureaucratic burdens without compromising security standards.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of addressing e-commerce risks through harmonized risk-based controls, fully supporting the issue's demand for improved data sharing and integration of anti-fraud clauses in trade agreements.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to address environmental impacts of increased trade flows, firmly disapproveing with their ecological priorities.  
GREEN_EFA opposes centralization of customs authority to EU level as undermining local governance capacities and subsidiarity principles.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the report's omission of pollution reduction mechanisms in customs modernization, overlooking critical aspects of sustainable trade facilitation.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the issue's implicit endorsement of carbon-intensive transport growth, contradicting their climate action commitments.  
GREEN_EFA completely againsts the technocratic approach to trade facilitation that fails to integrate ecological safeguards with customs reforms.

SD strongly sanctions the creation of a European control body to ensure uniform customs treatment across EU entry points, aligning with the issue's push for harmonized procedures.  
SD strongly endorses accelerated funding allocation for critical IT systems to achieve paperless customs processes, addressing the issue's identified risks of implementation delays.  
SD strongly approves enhanced coordination between customs authorities, OLAF, and EUIPO to combat illicit trade networks, directly supporting the issue's emphasis on inter-agency collaboration.  
SD strongly backs mandatory harmonized risk indicators and inspection quotas across all member states, fully aligning with the issue's strategy to eliminate procedural fragmentation.  
SD strongly sanctions explicit differentiation between administrative and criminal penalties in customs enforcement, proposing this clarification to strengthen the issue's sanctions harmonization framework.

ECR rejects the issue's approach to harmonized customs procedures as it fails to address the critical issue of member states' inconsistent enforcement, which directly leads to widespread customs legislation violations and revenue losses. This oversight totally rejects with ECR's demand for strict compliance mechanisms.  
ECR opposes the proposed cooperation frameworks for overlooking the urgent need to regulate free trade zones that enable smuggling and counterfeit goods proliferation, a gap inconsistent with ECR's emphasis on securing EU economic boundaries.  
The issue's focus on IT system modernization neglects the immediate requirement for physical inspections and border controls that ECR deems essential to combat the €10 billion tobacco smuggling crisis referenced in parliamentary findings.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the effectiveness of current risk management strategies in tackling "μαϊμού" counterfeit products, arguing the proposal lacks concrete measures to destroy illegal manufacturing networks aligned with organized crime.  
The absence of mandatory sanctions against non-compliant member states in the issue directly contradicts ECR's principle of equal accountability across all EU territories to prevent trade distortions and fiscal evasion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about challenges in implementing the Union Customs Code (UCC), emphasizing the need for harmonized, efficient customs procedures to safeguard EU revenues, combat illicit trade, and ensure security. It highlighted insufficient funding for critical IT systems, risking delays in achieving paper-free customs by 2020 and hindering the EU Strategy and Action Plan for customs risk management, particularly affecting the Import Control System. The resolution stressed the detrimental impact of fragmented customs practices among Member States, leading to administrative burdens, trade distortions, and revenue losses, including €1 billion in fiscal losses from Belarus in 2015. It noted the rise in counterfeit goods, with over 40 million items (valued at €650 million) seized in 2015, primarily from China (€300 million) and Hong Kong (€100 million), and highlighted tobacco-related illicit trade causing over €10 billion in annual revenue losses. The Parliament urged enhanced cooperation with third countries, international organizations, and the private sector to combat IPR infringements, terrorism financing, and organized crime, while promoting the Authorized Economic Operator (AEO) program and Smart and Secure Trade Lanes. It called for harmonized risk-based controls, improved data sharing, and stronger collaboration between customs authorities, OLAF, and market surveillance bodies to address e-commerce risks, VAT fraud, and preferential trade abuses. The resolution emphasized aligning customs and VAT policies, implementing the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement, and integrating anti-fraud clauses in trade agreements to protect EU financial interests, innovation, and consumer safety.

title: External impact of EU trade and investment policy outside the EU: REPORT on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in countries outside the EU
background: The EU's trade and investment policies, including public procurement directives and international agreements, influenced global public-private initiatives, with PPPs increasingly used for infrastructure and services in developing countries amid budgetary constraints. The Parliament will discuss the external effects of EU trade policy on third-country PPP frameworks, balancing economic growth and sustainable development objectives.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly sanctions the issue's emphasis on enhancing transparent governance and risk-sharing frameworks in public-private partnerships, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to fostering fair market access for European enterprises.  
ALDE applauds the focus on SME inclusion through clustered tendering and subcontracting mechanisms, which effectively advances ALDE's priority of empowering small and medium-sized businesses in global infrastructure markets.  
ALDE proposes strengthening implementation oversight to ensure stalled projects like the Istrian Ypsilon highway are expedited, emphasizing alignment with EU procurement directives without opposing the issue’s core principles.  
ALDE strongly endorses blending EU development aid with PPPs to maximize budgetary efficiency, matching ALDE’s 2023 manifesto goals on sustainable global growth through public-private collaboration.  
ALDE approves the call for gender mainstreaming and adherence to UN human rights principles in PPPs, reflecting ALDE’s unwavering advocacy for ethical and inclusive economic policies.

SD strongly promotes the issue's prioritization of SME inclusion through clustered tendering and EU agency support, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to equitable economic participation.  
SD applauds the emphasis on transparent governance frameworks for PPPs, which effectively advances SD's principles of accountability in public service delivery.  
SD endorses the risk-sharing mechanisms as critical to preventing fiscal imbalances, proposing enhanced definitions of risk transfer thresholds to ensure genuine public benefit.  
SD proposes strengthening safeguards against profit privatization in Article 12 by explicitly mandating "symmetrical liability clauses" to operationalize the issue's anti-exploitation objectives.  
SD emphasizes that PPP alignment with UN development goals and anti-corruption measures perfectly matches their manifesto focus on ethical globalization.

ECR strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on transparent governance and risk-sharing frameworks, aligning perfectly with ECR's commitment to fiscal responsibility and market-driven solutions in public-private partnerships.  
ECR approves the focus on SME inclusion through clustered tendering and EU agency support, effectively advancing ECR's priority of empowering small businesses as engines of cross-border economic growth.  
ECR proposes enhancing Article 12's technical assistance provisions by amending "alignment with national development plans" to explicitly include debt relief negotiations with IMF and regional development banks as a complementary measure.  
ECR applauds the linkage between PPPs and UN human rights standards, which matches ECR's longstanding advocacy for ethical corporate conduct in EU external trade policy.  
ECR urges stricter enforcement of reciprocity in procurement market access through trade agreements, suggesting Annex III reporting requirements be expanded to track third-country compliance biannually.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue's endorsement of PPPs as fully againsting with their opposition to capitalist integration models that transfer public investment control to corporate entities, exacerbating austerity and democratic erosion.  
GUE/NGL opposes the promotion of PPPs in developing countries, condemning the issue's failure to prevent debt unsustainability risks and taxpayer-funded corporate profit guarantees inconsistent with poverty reduction claims.  
GUE/NGL denounces the issue's market-liberalization focus through PPPs, which undermines universal access to public services like healthcare and education, directly contradicting social protection principles.  
GUE/NGL challenges the issue's reliance on voluntary corporate accountability frameworks, demanding binding human rights and environmental obligations instead of aspirational references to UN Guiding Principles.  
GUE/NGL rejects the linkage between PPPs and sustainable growth, highlighting the absence of enforceable safeguards against corruption and labor exploitation in EU trade agreements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of public-private partnerships (PPPs) as tools for economic growth, innovation, infrastructure modernization (notably in energy, water, transport, and digital sectors), and job creation, emphasizing their potential to address global challenges like sustainable development and budgetary constraints. It highlighted the EU’s leadership in PPPs, accounting for over 45% of the global PPP infrastructure market, and stressed the need for internationally recognized definitions, transparent governance, and risk-sharing frameworks to ensure cost-effectiveness, quality public services, and compliance with social, environmental, and human rights standards. The resolution underscored the role of SMEs, advocating for their inclusion through clustered tendering, transparent subcontracting, and support via EU agencies like EASME and EEN, while addressing barriers faced by EU companies in foreign procurement markets through trade agreements and reciprocal market access. It linked PPPs to development goals, urging technical assistance to developing countries for institutional capacity-building, alignment with national development plans, and poverty reduction, alongside safeguards against state indebtedness and corruption. Gender mainstreaming, adherence to UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, and corporate accountability were emphasized, alongside calls for blending mechanisms to mobilize private finance and EU initiatives like the European Fund for Strategic Investments to enhance global PPP participation. The Parliament also stressed the need for legal certainty, dispute resolution mechanisms, and alignment with EU procurement directives (2014/24/EU, 2014/25/EU, and 2014/23/EU) to ensure fair competition and long-term viability, projecting a 5% sustainable growth target in developing countries through responsible PPPs.

title: Macro-financial assistance to Jordan: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan
background: Jordan faces economic strain from regional instability, hosting over 1.4 million refugees amid declining tourism and trade due to conflicts in Syria and Iraq, with rising public debt and external financing needs. The Parliament will discuss providing additional EU financial support to address economic challenges and reinforce stability in a geopolitically critical partner country.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the €200 million macro-financial assistance as critical to stabilizing Jordan’s economy amid refugee pressures, aligning perfectly with EPP’s commitment to regional stability and humanitarian solidarity.  
EPP emphasizes strict conditionality linking disbursements to measurable progress in governance reforms and fiscal transparency, reflecting EPP’s prioritization of accountable development partnerships.  
EPP proposes enhancing future assistance to €350 million in 2017 to address Jordan’s deepening balance-of-payments needs while maintaining alignment with IMF program benchmarks.  
EPP applauds Jordan’s role as a strategic partner in counterterrorism and refugee integration, urging expanded EU-Jordan collaboration through trade facilitation and energy security initiatives.  
EPP underscores the necessity of rigorous monitoring mechanisms to ensure funds directly alleviate socioeconomic strains caused by hosting 1.3 million Syrian refugees, in line with EPP’s humanitarian values.

ENF opposes the unilateral focus on Jordan, arguing it overlooks Lebanon’s greater refugee burden and stability efforts.  
ENF rejects human rights conditionality as ineffective, advocating instead for realpolitik prioritizing resistance to Islamist threats.  
ENF criticizes the proposal for failing to allocate resources to Christian communities destabilized by radical Islamism.  
ENF demands equal assistance to Lebanon, citing its recent political stabilization and disproportionate lack of international support.  
ENF entirely rejects the EU’s foreign policy framework, urging revision to address all regional actors resisting destabilization.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the €200 million assistance package as vital reinforcement of Jordan’s refugee-hosting efforts, aligning perfectly with GREEN_EFA’s commitment to global solidarity and humane migration policies.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the conditionality linking funds to democratic principles and social reforms, mirroring their manifesto priorities for accountable governance and human rights advancement.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending the assistance timeline to include a multi-annual framework, ensuring sustained support beyond this single disbursement to address protracted refugee needs.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that Jordan’s burden-sharing model should catalyze enhanced EU responsibility-sharing mechanisms, particularly urging member states to increase refugee resettlement quotas.  
GREEN_EFA urges adding explicit monitoring benchmarks for public finance reforms to the disbursement criteria, enhancing the issue’s existing transparency safeguards.

GUE_NGL rejects the conditional loan structure as fundamentally disputeing with their demand for non-restrictive aid to address Jordan's humanitarian crisis.  
GUE_NGL opposes linking assistance to IMF programs, citing historical incompatibility with social equity and public service expansion priorities.  
GUE_NGL condemns the reliance on debt-inducing loans instead of advocating grants and debt relief through EU neighborhood funds, as proposed in their intervention.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to ensure economic autonomy for Jordan, particularly in water/energy infrastructure strained by refugee inflows.  
GUE_NGL demands removal of governance conditionalities, arguing they perpetuate austerity measures contradicting social protection principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the approval of a €200 million macro-financial assistance package to Jordan to support its economic stabilization and reforms amid regional instability and the Syrian refugee crisis. The assistance, provided as medium-term loans, aims to address Jordan’s balance-of-payments needs and strengthen its fiscal sustainability, while promoting structural reforms in public finance management, governance, and social policies. The resolution emphasized strict conditionality, requiring Jordan to uphold democratic principles, human rights, and the rule of law, and to implement agreed reforms under IMF programs. It highlighted the disproportionate burden Jordan bears due to hosting over 1.3 million Syrian refugees, stressing the EU’s commitment to alleviating socioeconomic pressures and fostering regional stability. The Parliament urged the Commission to ensure transparency and accountability in disbursements, linking funds to measurable progress in reform implementation and adherence to partnership priorities, including combating corruption and improving public sector efficiency.

title: Macro-financial assistance to Tunisia: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to Tunisia
background: Tunisia faced economic instability following 2015 terrorist attacks, tourism decline, high unemployment, and hosting over 1.8 million Libyan refugees amid democratic transition post-2011 Arab Spring. The EU, with existing partnership and prior financial support, proposed further macro-financial assistance. The Parliament will discuss additional EU financial aid to Tunisia for economic stabilization and reform programs.

stances.stance:
ENF opposes fundamentally the provision of macro-financial assistance as institutionalized EU overreach contradicting national sovereignty principles.  
ENF rejects the linkage of aid to governance conditions, citing inherent interference in Tunisia’s domestic political equilibrium.  
This entirely rejects with ENF’s position that trade liberalization and EU-aligned structural reforms destabilize vulnerable economies.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as exacerbating Tunisia’s security fragility through externally imposed economic dependencies.  
ENF condemns the free-trade zone provisions as neo-colonial economic subjugation inconsistent with mutually respectful cooperation.

GREEN_EFA firmly advocates the €500 million assistance package as perfectly aligning with their commitment to democratic solidarity and sustainable development in neighboring regions.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the conditional governance framework emphasizing anti-corruption and transparency, directly advancing their manifesto priorities for accountable institutions.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s grant component as a critical step toward equitable debt justice, resonating with their longstanding advocacy for odious debt relief.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that the quarterly monitoring mechanisms align perfectly with their principles of ensuring aid directly benefits Tunisian civil society and environmental resilience.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue’s geopolitical importance in prioritizing democratic partners like Tunisia over authoritarian regimes, matching their vision for ethical EU external action.

SD completely sanctions the €500 million assistance package as a critical demonstration of solidarity with Tunisia's democratic transition, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to fostering sustainable development and political accountability in the Mediterranean region.  
SD applauds the conditional framework linking aid to IMF program adherence and governance reforms, which mirrors SD's longstanding prioritization of transparency, anti-corruption, and multiparty democracy.  
SD urges immediate action to repatriate Ben Ali-era assets held in EU banks, framing this as an essential enhancement to complement macro-financial assistance and rectify historical injustices.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of asymmetrical trade relations with Tunisia, underscoring how the issue’s support for progressive free trade agreements advances equitable economic partnerships.  
SD highlights Tunisia’s role as a regional democratic model and stresses that the aid’s focus on stabilizing tourism and key sectors perfectly aligns with SD’s strategic goal of combating destabilization through targeted economic resilience measures.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposed macro-financial assistance as it absolutely doubts with the party's anti-austerity principles by enforcing IMF structural reforms that perpetuate debt dependency and erode Tunisia's economic sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's conditionalities as inconsistent with democratic solidarity, citing how imposed liberalization agendas historically exacerbate social inequalities contrary to sustainable development goals.  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to address systemic debt relief or repatriate Ben Ali's confiscated assets, which the proposal overlooks despite being critical to equitable recovery.  
GUE_NGL rejects the linkage between financial aid and macroeconomic adjustments that prioritize fiscal discipline over public welfare, mirroring harmful EU austerity models.  
GUE_NGL demands alternative mechanisms such as debt-free grants for sustainable employment projects, rejecting loan-based frameworks that deepen neoliberal exploitation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the approval of macro-financial assistance to Tunisia, endorsing a €500 million package comprising €400 million in loans and €100 million in grants to address the country’s balance-of-payments challenges and support economic reforms. The assistance, spanning two and a half years, is conditional on Tunisia’s adherence to IMF programs, progress in structural reforms, and commitments to democracy, anti-corruption, and transparency. The resolution emphasized strict monitoring by the Commission, requiring quarterly reports to Parliament and Council on Tunisia’s reform implementation, macroeconomic performance, and compliance with governance conditions. Parliament also approved a joint statement with the Council, annexed to the resolution, and stressed that any substantial amendments to the proposal by the Commission must be resubmitted for parliamentary scrutiny. The aid aims to stabilize Tunisia’s economy while promoting sustainable development and political accountability.

title: Further macro-financial assistance to Ukraine: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to Ukraine
background: Following Russia’s 2014 annexation of Crimea and ongoing conflict in eastern Ukraine, Ukraine faced prolonged economic instability, requiring multiple EU macro-financial assistance programs. Persistent challenges included debt obligations, defense spending, and anti-corruption reforms, notably delayed implementation of judicial measures. The Parliament will discuss a fourth €1 billion assistance package tied to governance and economic reforms.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the provision of further macro-financial assistance to Ukraine due to systemic corruption undermining accountability, as evidenced by the politically motivated dismissal of officials exposing graft.  
EFDD opposes fundamentally the disbursement without IMF-level scrutiny, noting Ukraine’s failure to establish an anti-corruption court or protect whistleblowers like Nadia Savchenko.  
The issue’s reliance on unenforced memoranda contradicts EFDD’s demand for pre-verified anti-corruption benchmarks, mirroring the IMF’s withholding stance.  
EFDD highlights the Commission’s disregard for Ukraine’s non-compliance with trade rules, such as its wood export ban, as indicative of flawed conditionality mechanisms.  
This proposal overlooks EFDD’s core principle that taxpayer funds require ironclad safeguards against misuse by regimes ranked among Europe’s most corrupt.

ENF opposes fundamentally the macro-financial assistance, citing Ukraine’s entrenched corruption and governance failures as irreconcilable with the issue’s democracy preconditions.  
ENF rejects the prioritization of geopolitical tensions with Russia, asserting the aid perpetuates Brussels’ confrontational agenda rather than addressing systemic Ukrainian reforms.  
ENF condemns the Commission’s procedural overreach, arguing the limited amendments to the decision undermine parliamentary sovereignty and institutional balance.  
ENF highlights the issue’s failure to address agricultural sector losses from EU-Russia sanctions, demanding funds be redirected to compensate affected European farmers.  
ENF disputes the efficacy of automated asset verification systems, claiming the issue overlooks Ukraine’s institutional incapacity to implement anti-corruption measures credibly.

ALDE totally endorses the streamlined conditionality of the MFA IV programme, recognizing Ukraine’s demonstrated capacity to deliver reforms under clear EU expectations.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on Ukraine’s anti-corruption advancements, particularly highlighting the establishment of the High Anti-Corruption Court as pivotal to European integration.  
ALDE commends the issue’s acknowledgment of Ukraine’s legislative achievements in pension, healthcare, and education reforms amid wartime challenges.  
ALDE underscores the EU’s responsibility to structure assistance that safeguards Ukraine’s socio-economic stability while advancing governance reforms.  
ALDE totally endorses the expedited approval mechanism, ensuring rapid deployment of assistance while maintaining rigorous reform benchmarks.

SD strongly advocates the stringent anti-corruption conditions tied to MFA IV, particularly the automated asset verification system, aligning with their commitment to democratic governance and institutional accountability.  
SD approves the prioritization of EU-Ukraine expert exchanges on beneficial ownership transparency, urging tangible benchmarks to prevent elite capture of assistance funds.  
SD proposes enhancing the Memorandum’s social dimensions by explicitly linking trade compliance to sustainable job creation and poverty reduction, reflecting Ukraine’s need for equitable growth.  
SD underscores the necessity for rigorous Commission monitoring of judicial reforms, including the operationalization of Ukraine’s anti-corruption court, as a precondition for disbursing subsequent tranches.  
SD welcomes the issue’s focus on expedited approval processes while insisting gender parity in reform oversight bodies be added to strengthen civil society inclusion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for stringent conditions tied to Ukraine’s receipt of macro-financial assistance (MFA) under the MFA IV programme, emphasizing anti-corruption measures, trade compliance, and governance reforms. It demanded the establishment of an automated verification system for public officials’ asset declarations, requiring direct access to state databases and prioritization of high-level officials, with significant progress mandated by the disbursement of the second tranche. The resolution called for expert EU-Ukraine exchanges to develop a verification mechanism for beneficial ownership data, with tangible benchmarks integrated into the MFA IV Memorandum. It highlighted Ukraine’s non-compliant wood export ban, urging the Commission to resolve this via trade instruments, including dispute settlement mechanisms. The Parliament reaffirmed pre-conditions on democracy, rule of law, and anti-corruption, insisting that the Commission and European External Action Service (EEAS) rigorously monitor compliance, withholding disbursements until objectives are met. To expedite approval, amendments to the decision were limited to two, focusing on a recital and an article to facilitate swift agreement between Parliament and the Council.

title: Introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia
background: Following Tunisia's democratic transition post-2011 Arab Spring, terrorist attacks caused economic instability, including tourism decline and high youth unemployment, amid regional security challenges. The Parliament will discuss introducing temporary EU autonomous trade measures, focusing on olive oil tariff exemptions to support Tunisia's economy.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the proposal's tariff elimination as absolutely disputeing with their agricultural protection principles, citing direct harm to Southern European olive oil producers.  
EFDD opposes the measure's fraud risks highlighted by Rosa D'Amato, noting the issue fails to address documented olive oil relabeling schemes undermining "made in Italy" authenticity.  
EFDD condemns the initiative for overlooking critical aspects like sector-wide economic impacts, contradicting their demands for EU-wide burden-sharing in Mediterranean development.
